Premise2: It is impossible to have desires without also being a moral agent

Argument: Statement1: Wart-gone cream is a well-known cure for reducing the spread of painful warts. A dime size amount rubbed on the infected area daily is the prescribed dosage, and applying the cream more often does not enhance the cream's healing effects. Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will not boost sales and, therefore, will not increase profits either. 
Premise1: The $3. 00 coupons, if distributed, would not induce new customers, who might not have purchased the product otherwise, to try wart-gone. 
Premise2: Wart-gone can be produced in small or large batches without appreciably lowering the pre-tube production costs.

Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will boost produce and, however, will not change pre-tube production costs much.

Argument: Statement1: Until he was dismissed amid great controversy, hastings was considered one of the greatest intelligence agents of all time. Soon after the dismissal, however, it was shown that he had never been incompetent. Statement2: It is clear that if his dismissal was justified, then hastings was either incompetent or else disloyal. Statement3: Thus, one is forced to conclude that hastings must have been disloyal.
Premise1: Hastings's dismissal was justified.
Premise2: If someone was disloyal or incompetent, then his dismissal was justified.

output: Statement1: Until he was dismissed amid great controversy, hastings was considered one of the greatest intelligence agents of all time. Soon after the dismissal, however, it was shown that he had never been incompetent. Statement2: It is clear that his dismissal was justified. Statement4: Thus, one is forced to conclude that hastings must have been disloyal.

input_info.Om: Premise2: If someone was disloyal or incompetent, then his dismissal was justified.
input_info.O: Premise1: Hastings's dismissal was justified.
input_info.P: Statement1: Until he was dismissed amid great controversy, hastings was considered one of the greatest intelligence agents of all time. Soon after the dismissal, however, it was shown that he had never been incompetent. Statement2: It is clear that if his dismissal was justified, then hastings was either incompetent or else disloyal. Statement3: Thus, one is forced to conclude that hastings must have been disloyal.

Argument: Statement1: The press reports on political campaigns these days as if they were chess games. Statement2: One candidate's campaign advisor makes a move ; the other candidate's advisor makes a countermove. Statement3: The press then reports on the campaign advisors and not on the candidates. Statement4: The losers in this chess game are the voters. Statement5: They are deprived of the information they need to make informed decisions because the press is ignoring substantive policy issues and reporting only on the process of the campaign. Statement6: It is clear that the campaign advisors should stay out of the limelight and let the press report on the most revealing positions on substantive issues the candidates have taken.
Premise1: The candidates in the election are taking positions on substantive policy issues.
Premise2: There is no difference between reporting on the political process and reporting on substantive issues.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The press reports on political campaigns these days as if they were chess games. Statement2: One candidate's campaign advisor makes a move ; the other candidate's advisor makes a countermove. Statement3: The press then reports on the campaign advisors and not on the candidates. Statement4: . Statement5: And the press is reporting only on the process of the campaign. Statement6: It is clear that the press reports on the most revealing positions on substantive issues the candidates have taken.

input_info.Om: Premise2: There is no difference between reporting on the political process and reporting on substantive issues.
input_info.O: Premise1: The candidates in the election are taking positions on substantive policy issues.
input_info.P: Statement1: The press reports on political campaigns these days as if they were chess games. Argument: Statement1: Tiger sharks are common in the waters surrounding tenare island. Statement2: Usually tiger sharks feed on smaller sharks, but sometimes they have attacked tourists swimming and surfing at tenare's beaches. Statement3: This has hurt tenare's tourism industry, which is second only to its fishing industry in annual revenues. Statement4: In order to help the economy, therefore, the mayor of the island has proposed an ongoing program to kill any tiger sharks within a mile of the beaches.
Premise1: The small sharks on which tiger sharks prey feed on fish that are commercially important to the island's fisheries.
Premise2: Not all tourists who come to tenare island enjoy swimming or surfing.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Tiger sharks are common in the waters surrounding tenare island. Statement2: Usually tiger sharks feed on smaller sharks, but sometimes they have attacked tourists swimming and surfing at tenare's beaches. Statement3: If all the tourists were attacked by tiger sharks, it would cause damage to tenare's tourism industry, which is second only to its fishing industry in annual revenues. Statement4: In order to help the economy, therefore, the mayor of the island has proposed an ongoing program to kill any tiger sharks within a mile of the beaches.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most strongly calls into question the likelihood that implementation of the mayor's proposal will have the desired consequence?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Not all tourists who come to tenare island enjoy swimming or surfing.
input_info.O: Premise1: The small sharks on which tiger sharks prey feed on fish that are commercially important to the island's fisheries.

Statement2: Usually tiger sharks feed on smaller sharks, but sometimes they have attacked tourists swimming and surfing at tenare's beaches. Statement3: This has hurt tenare's tourism industry, which is second only to its fishing industry in annual revenues. Statement4: In order to help the economy, therefore, the mayor of the island has proposed an ongoing program to kill any tiger sharks within a mile of the beaches.

Argument: Statement1: Columnist : shortsighted motorists learn the hard way about the wisdom of preventive auto maintenance ; such maintenance almost always pays off in the long run. Premise2: Even some cars that receive regular preventive maintenance break down, requiring costly repairs.

Premise2: Some newspaper editors do not regard journalism schools as a necessary part of the training of a journalist.

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: In defending the hyperion school of journalism from charges that its program is of little or no value to its students, the dean of the school pointed to its recent success in placing students : the journalism regards journalism schools as a necessary part of the training of a journalist.

Argument: Statement1: Critic : works of literature often present protagonists who scorn allegiance to their society and who advocate detachment rather than civic-mindedness. However, modern literature is distinguished from the literature of earlier eras in part because it more frequently treats such protagonists sympathetically. Statement2: Sympathetic treatment of such characters suggests to readers that one should be unconcerned about contributing to societal good. Statement3: Thus, modern literature can damage individuals who appropriate this attitude, as well as damage society at large.
Premise1: It is to the advantage of some individuals that they be concerned with contributing to societal good.
Premise2: Some individuals must believe that their society is better than most before they can become concerned with benefiting it.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Critic : works of literature often present protagonists who scorn allegiance to their society and who advocate detachment rather than civic-mindedness. However, modern literature is distinguished from the literature of earlier eras in part because it more frequently treats such protagonists sympathetically. Statement3: Sympathetic treatment of such characters suggests to readers that one should not believe that their society is better than most. Statement4: Thus, modern literature can damage individuals who appropriate this attitude, as well as damage society at large.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the critic's argument relies?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Some individuals must believe that their society is better than most before they can become concerned with benefiting it.
input_info.O: Premise1: It is to the advantage of some individuals that they be concerned with contributing to societal good.
input_info.P: Statement1: Critic : works of literature often present protagonists who scorn allegiance to their society and who advocate detachment rather than civic-mindedness. However, modern literature is distinguished from the literature of earlier eras in part because it more frequently treats such protagonists sympathetically. Statement2: Sympathetic treatment of such characters suggests to readers that one should be unconcerned about contributing to societal good. Statement3: Thus, modern literature can damage individuals who appropriate this attitude, as well as damage society at large.

Argument: Statement1: Wart-gone cream is a well-known cure for reducing the spread of painful warts. A dime size amount rubbed on the infected area daily is the prescribed dosage, and applying the cream more often does not enhance the cream's healing effects. Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will not boost sales and, therefore, will not increase profits either. 
Premise1: The $3. 00 coupons, if distributed, would not induce new customers, who might not have purchased the product otherwise, to try wart-gone. 
Premise2: Wart-gone can be produced in small or large batches without appreciably lowering the pre-tube production costs.

Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will boost produce and, however, will not change pre-tube production costs much.

Argument: Statement1: The profitability of a business is reduced by anything that undermines employee morale. Statement2: This is why paying senior staff with stock options, which allows them to earn more when the enterprise prospers, is not a wise policy because it increases dramatically the difference in income between senior staff and employees who are paid only a fixed salary.
Premise1: Large income differences between fixed-salary employees and senior staff tend to undermine employee morale.
Premise2: Employees whose incomes rise as the profits of their employers rise are more productive than those paid only a fixed salary.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The profitability of a business is increased by anything that encourages employee morale. Statement2: This is why paying senior staff with stock options, which allows them to earn more when the enterprise prospers, is a wise policy because it increases dramatically the difference in income between senior staff and employees who are paid only a fixed salary.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Employees whose incomes rise as the profits of their employers rise are more productive than those paid only a fixed salary.
input_info.O: Premise1: Large income differences between fixed-salary employees and senior staff tend to undermine employee morale.
input_info.P: Statement1: The profitability of a business is reduced by anything that undermines employee morale. Statement2: This is why paying senior staff with stock options, which allows them to earn more when the enterprise prospers, is not a wise policy because it increases dramatically the difference in income between senior staff and employees who are paid only a fixed salary.

Argument: Statement1: Harry trevalga : you and your publication have unfairly discriminated against my poems. Statement2: I have submitted thirty poems in the last two years and you have not published any of them! Statement3: It is all because i won the fenner poetry award two years ago and your poetry editor thought she deserved it. Statement4: Publisher : ridiculous! Statement5: Our editorial policy and practice is perfectly fair, since our poetry editor judges all submissions for publication without ever seeing the names of the poets, and hence can not possibly have known who wrote your poems.
Premise1: The poetry editor cannot recognize the poems submitted by harry trevalga as his unless trevalga's name is attached to them.
Premise2: The poetry editor's decisions on which poems to publish are not based strictly on judgments of intrinsic merit.

Argument: Statement1: It is widely assumed that people need to engage in intellectual activities such as solving crossword puzzles or mathematics problems in order to maintain mental sharpness as they age. In fact, however, simply talking to other people -- that is, participating in social interaction, which engages many mental and perceptual skills -- suffices. Statement2: Evidence to this effect comes from a study showing that the more social contact people report, the better their mental skills.
Premise1: Many medical conditions and treatments that adversely affect a person's mental sharpness also tend to increase that person's social isolation.
Premise2: The tasks evaluating mental sharpness for which data were compiled by the study were more akin to mathematics problems than to conversation.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: It is widely assumed that people need to engage in intellectual activities such as solving crossword puzzles or mathematics problems in order to maintain mental sharpness as they age. In fact, however, simply talking to other people -- that is, participating in social interaction, which engages many mental and perceptual skills -- suffices. Statement3: Evidence to this effect comes from a study showing that the more social conversations people report, the better their mental skills.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the force of the evidence cited?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The tasks evaluating mental sharpness for which data were compiled by the study were more akin to mathematics problems than to conversation.
input_info.O: Premise1: Many medical conditions and treatments that adversely affect a person's mental sharpness also tend to increase that person's social isolation.
input_info.P: Statement1: It is widely assumed that people need to engage in intellectual activities such as solving crossword puzzles or mathematics problems in order to maintain mental sharpness as they age. In fact, however, simply talking to other people -- that is, participating in social interaction, which engages many mental and perceptual skills -- suffices. Statement2: Evidence to this effect comes from a study showing that the more social contact people report, the better their mental skills.

Argument: Statement1: A recent epidemiological study found that businesspeople who travel internationally on business are much more likely to suffer from chronic insomnia than are businesspeople who do not travel on business. International travelers experience the stresses of dramatic changes in climate, frequent disruption of daily routines, and immersion in cultures other than their own, stresses not commonly felt by those who do not travel. Statement2: Thus, it is likely that these stresses cause the insomnia.
Premise1: Businesspeople who already suffer from chronic insomnia are no more likely than businesspeople who do not to accept assignments from their employers that require international travel.
Premise2: Experiencing dramatic changes in climate and disruption of daily routines through international travel can be beneficial to some people who suffer from chronic insomnia.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A recent epidemiological study found that businesspeople who travel internationally on business are much less likely to suffer from chronic insomnia than are businesspeople who do not travel on business. International travelers experience the stresses of dramatic changes in climate, frequent disruption of daily routines, and immersion in cultures other than their own, stresses not commonly felt by those who do not travel. Statement3: Thus, it is likely that these stresses cure the insomnia.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following would, if true, most strengthen the reasoning above?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Experiencing dramatic changes in climate and disruption of daily routines through international travel can be beneficial to some people who suffer from chronic insomnia.
input_info.O: Premise1: Businesspeople who already suffer from chronic insomnia are no more likely than businesspeople who do not to accept assignments from their employers that require international travel.
input_info.P: Statement1: A recent epidemiological study found that businesspeople who travel internationally on business are much more likely to suffer from chronic insomnia than are businesspeople who do not travel on business. International travelers experience the stresses of dramatic changes in climate, frequent disruption of daily routines, and immersion in cultures other than their own, stresses not commonly felt by those who do not travel. Statement2: Thus, it is likely that these stresses cause the insomnia.

Argument: Statement1: The everyday behavior of whales is particularly difficult to study because introducing novel stimuli, such as divers or submarines, into the whales'environment causes whales to behave in unusual ways. Statement2: Some biologists plan to train sea lions to carry video cameras on their backs and, on command, to swim along with whales. Statement3: They argue that since whales are accustomed to there being sea lions nearby, using the sea lions to film the whales would allow biologists to study the everyday behavior of the whales.
Premise1: The behavior of the sea lions under human command will be within the range of sea lion behavior to which the whales are accustomed.
Premise2: Sea lions carrying video cameras will be able to film whales at a much closer range than divers can.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The everyday behavior of whales is particularly difficult to study because divers and submarines can safely stay near whales, but it is difficult to get close to them. Only photographic material taken at close range has research value. Statement2: Some biologists plan to train sea lions to carry video cameras on their backs and to swim along with whales. Statement3: They argue that since whales are accustomed to there being sea lions nearby, using the sea lions to film the whales would allow biologists to study the everyday behavior of the whales.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the biologists' reasoning depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Sea lions carrying video cameras will be able to film whales at a much closer range than divers can.
input_info.O: Premise1: The behavior of the sea lions under human command will be within the range of sea lion behavior to which the whales are accustomed.
input_info.P: Statement1: The everyday behavior of whales is particularly difficult to study because introducing novel stimuli, such as divers or submarines, into the whales'environment causes whales to behave in unusual ways. Statement2: Some biologists plan to train sea lions to carry video cameras on their backs and, on command, to swim along with whales. Statement3: They argue that since whales are accustomed to there being sea lions nearby, using the sea lions to film the whales would allow biologists to study the everyday behavior of the whales.

Argument: Statement1: Efforts to get the public to exercise regularly, which have emphasized the positive health effects of exercise rather than the dangers of a sedentary lifestyle, have met with little success. Statement2: In contrast, efforts to curb cigarette smoking, which have emphasized the dangers of smoking rather than the positive health effects of quitting, have been highly successful. Statement3: Thus, efforts to get the public to exercise regularly would be more successful if they emphasized the dangers of a sedentary lifestyle rather than the positive health effects of exercise.

Premise2: The majority of people who successfully quit smoking cite health concerns as the primary motivation for their success.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Efforts to get the public to exercise regularly, which have emphasized the normal negativehealth effects of exercise have met with little success. Statement2: In contrast, efforts to curb cigarette smoking, which have emphasized the fact that it will increase the probability of lung cancer, have been highly successful. Statement3: Thus, efforts to get the public to exercise regularly would be more successful if they emphasized the fact that sedentary lifestyle will also increase the probability of people getting some fatal diseases.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The majority of people who successfully quit smoking cite health concerns as the primary motivation for their success.

Argument: Statement1: Tiger beetles are such fast runners that they can capture virtually any nonflying insect. However, when running toward an insect, the beetles intermittently stop, and then, a moment later, resume their attack. Statement2: Perhaps they can not maintain their pace and must pause for a moment's rest ; but an alternative hypothesis is that while running tiger beetles are unable to process the resulting rapidly changing visual information, and so quickly go blind and stop.
Premise1: The beetles maintain a fixed time interval between pauses, although when an insect that had been stationary begins to flee, the beetle increases its speed after its next pause.
Premise2: If, when a beetle pauses, it has not gained on the insect it is pursuing, the beetle generally ends its pursuit.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Tiger beetles are such fast runners that they can capture virtually any nonflying insect. However, when running toward an insect, the beetles stop, and then, end persuit. Statement3: Perhaps they can not maintain their pace and must pause for a moment's rest and then resume their attack; but an alternative hypothesis is that while running tiger beetles are unable to process the resulting rapidly changing visual information, and so quickly go blind and end persuit.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if discovered in experiments using artificially moved prey insects, would support one of the two hypotheses and undermine the other?
input_info.Om: Premise2: If, when a beetle pauses, it has not gained on the insect it is pursuing, the beetle generally ends its pursuit.
input_info.O: Premise1: The beetles maintain a fixed time interval between pauses, although when an insect that had been stationary begins to flee, the beetle increases its speed after its next pause.
input_info.P: Statement1: Tiger beetles are such fast runners that they can capture virtually any nonflying insect. However, when running toward an insect, the beetles intermittently stop, and then, a moment later, resume their attack. Statement2: Perhaps they can not maintain their pace and must pause for a moment's rest ; but an alternative hypothesis is that while running tiger beetles are unable to process the resulting rapidly changing visual information, and so quickly go blind and stop.

Argument: Statement1: Appliance dealer : appliance manufacturers commonly modify existing models without giving the modified versions new model names. input_info.Om: Premise2: Abstract painting cannot stimulate people to act.
input_info.O: Premise1: Paintings that fail to move a viewer to political action cannot be politically significant.

Statement2: Therefore, abstract painting can never be a politically significant art form.

Argument: Statement1: In a study conducted in pennsylvania, servers in various restaurants wrote" thank you" on randomly selected bills before presenting the bills to their customers. Statement2: Tips on these bills were an average of three percentage points higher than tips on bills without the message. Statement3: Therefore, if servers in pennsylvania regularly wrote" thank you" on restaurant bills, their average income from tips would be significantly higher than it otherwise would have been.
Premise1: Regularly seeing "thank you" written on their bills would not lead restaurant patrons to revert to their earlier tipping habits.
Premise2: The "thank you" messages would have the same impact on regular patrons of a restaurant as they would on occasional patrons of the same restaurant.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: In a study conducted in pennsylvania, servers in various restaurants wrote" thank you" on randomly selected bills before presenting the bills to their occasional patrons. Statement2: Tips on these bills were an average of three percentage points higher than tips on bills without the message. Statement3: Therefore, if servers in pennsylvania regularly wrote" thank you" on restaurant bills, their average income from tips of regular patrons would be significantly higher than it otherwise would have been.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The "thank you" messages would have the same impact on regular patrons of a restaurant as they would on occasional patrons of the same restaurant.
input_info.O: Premise1: Regularly seeing "thank you" written on their bills would not lead restaurant patrons to revert to their earlier tipping habits.
input_info.P: Statement1: In a study conducted in pennsylvania, servers in various restaurants wrote" thank you" on randomly selected bills before presenting the bills to their customers. Argument: Statement1: Manufacturers of writing paper need to add mineral" filler" to paper pulp if the paper made from the pulp is to look white. Argument: Statement1: Commentator : many people argue that the release of chlorofluorocarbons into the atmosphere is harming humans by damaging the ozone layer, thus allowing increased amounts of ultraviolet radiation to reach earth. Premise2: Extraterrestrial influences on the ozone layer tend to occur less often than terrestrial ones.

Argument: Statement1: Over 40,000 lead seals from the early byzantine empire remain today. Statement2: Apart from the rare cases where the seal authenticated a document of special importance, most seals had served their purpose when the document was opened. Statement3: Lead was not expensive, but it was not free : most lead seals would have been recast once they had served their purpose. Statement4: Thus the number of early byzantine documents sealed in such a fashion must have been many times the number of remaining lead seals.
Premise1: Most of the lead seals produced during the early byzantine empire were affixed to documents that were then opened during that period.
Premise2: During the time of the early byzantine empire there were at most 40, 000 documents of enough importance to prevent the removing and recycling of the seal.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Over 40,000 lead seals from the early byzantine empire remain today. Statement2: Apart from the rare cases where the lead seal authenticated a document of special importance and therefore being saved, rest of lead seals had served their purpose when the document was opened. Statement3: Lead was not expensive, but it was not free : lead seals would have been recast once they had served their purpose. Statement4: Thus the number of early byzantine documents sealed in such a fashion must have been many times the number of remaining lead seals.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following statements, if true, most strengthens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: During the time of the early byzantine empire there were at most 40, 000 documents of enough importance to prevent the removing and recycling of the seal.
input_info.O: Premise1: Most of the lead seals produced during the early byzantine empire were affixed to documents that were then opened during that period.
input_info.P: Statement1: Over 40,000 lead seals from the early byzantine empire remain today. Statement3: Lead was not expensive, but it was not free : most lead seals would have been recast once they had served their purpose. Statement4: Thus the number of early byzantine documents sealed in such a fashion must have been many times the number of remaining lead seals.

Argument: Statement1: A recent study suggests that alzheimer's disease, which attacks the human brain, may be caused by a virus. Statement2: In the study, blood from 11 volunteers, each of whom had the disease, was injected into rats. Statement3: The rats eventually exhibited symptoms of another degenerative neurological disorder, creutzfeldt-jakob disease, which is caused by a virus. Statement4: This led the scientist who conducted the study to conclude that alzheimer's disease might be caused by a virus.
Premise1: The symptoms known, respectively, as creutzfeldt-jakob disease and alzheimer's disease are different manifestations of the same disease.
Premise2: Creutzfeldt-jakob disease affects only motor nerves in rats' limbs, not their brains.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A recent study suggests that alzheimer's disease, which attacks the human brain, may be caused by a virus. Statement2: In the study, blood from 11 volunteers, each of whom had the disease, was injected into rats. Statement3: The rats eventually exhibited symptoms of another degenerative neurological disorder, creutzfeldt-jakob disease, which is caused by virus mutation. Statement4: The source of virus variation can only be another virus. Meanwhile, the mutated virus is more likely to attack from the limbs. This led the scientist who conducted the study to conclude that alzheimer's disease might be caused by a virus.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following statements, if true, would most strengthen the scientist's hypothesis that alzheimer's disease is caused by a virus?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Creutzfeldt-jakob disease affects only motor nerves in rats' limbs, not their brains.
input_info.O: Premise1: The symptoms known, respectively, as creutzfeldt-jakob disease and alzheimer's disease are different manifestations of the same disease.
input_info.P: Statement1: A recent study suggests that alzheimer's disease, which attacks the human brain, may be caused by a virus. Statement3: The rats eventually exhibited symptoms of another degenerative neurological disorder, creutzfeldt-jakob disease, which is caused by a virus. Statement4: This led the scientist who conducted the study to conclude that alzheimer's disease might be caused by a virus.

Argument: Statement1: Criminologist : a judicial system that tries and punishes criminals without delay is an effective deterrent to violent crime. Statement2: Long, drawn-out trials and successful legal maneuvering may add to criminals'feelings of invulnerability. Statement3: But if potential violent criminals know that being caught means prompt punishment, they will hesitate to break the law.
Premise1: It is in the nature of violent crime that it is not premeditated.
Premise2: Many violent crimes are committed by first- time offenders.

Statement2: Long, drawn-out trials and successful legal maneuvering may add to criminals'feelings of invulnerability. Statement3: But if violent criminals who has been punished by law because of previous violent crimes know that being caught means prompt punishment, they will hesitate to commit another premeditated violent crime.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Many violent crimes are committed by first- time offenders.

Statement3: But if potential violent criminals know that being caught means prompt punishment, they will hesitate to break the law.

Argument: Statement1: Spiders of many species change color to match the pigmentation of the flowers they sit on. Statement2: The insects preyed on by those spiders, unlike human beings, possess color discrimination so acute that they can readily see the spiders despite the seeming camouflage. Statement3: Clearly, then, it must be in evading their own predators that the spiders'color changes are useful to them.
Premise1: The color discrimination of certain birds that feed on color-changing spiders is no more acute than that of human beings.
Premise2: Color-changing spiders possess color discrimination that is more acute than that of spiders that lack the ability to change color.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Spiders of many species change color to match the pigmentation of the flowers they sit on. Statement2: The insects preyed on by those spiders, unlike human beings, possess color discrimination and sometimes they can see the spiders despite the seeming camouflage. And the insects can always see the spiders without the ability to change color. Statement3: So, those spiders will try their best to hide themselves in the petals of similar colors to prevent themselves from being found.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Color-changing spiders possess color discrimination that is more acute than that of spiders that lack the ability to change color.
input_info.O: Premise1: The color discrimination of certain birds that feed on color-changing spiders is no more acute than that of human beings.
input_info.P: Statement1: Spiders of many species change color to match the pigmentation of the flowers they sit on. Statement2: The insects preyed on by those spiders, unlike human beings, possess color discrimination so acute that they can readily see the spiders despite the seeming camouflage. Statement3: Clearly, then, it must be in evading their own predators that the spiders'color changes are useful to them.

Argument: Statement1: In the late 1980's, the population of sea otters in the north pacific ocean began to decline. Statement2: Of the two plausible explanations for the decline-increased predation by killer whales or disease-disease is the more likely.
Premise1: Killer whales in the north pacific usually prey on seals and sea lions but will, when this food source is scarce, seek out other prey.
Premise2: There is no indication that substantial numbers of sea otters migrated to other locations from the north pacific in the 1980's.

Statement2: Of the two plausible explanations for the decline-increased predation by killer whales or migration-migration is the more likely.

Argument: Statement1: A survey has shown that public perceptions of comparative risks differ radically from the assessments of risk-management experts. Statement2: For example, living near a nuclear power plant was judged a much greater risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. On the other hand, exposure to x-rays was judged a significantly lower risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. Statement3: Psychologists have found that people tend to be more worried about risks they consider involuntary than about risks they consider voluntary. Statement4: Thus the survey results were probably caused by the respondents'tendency to consider involuntary risks to be greater than they actually are.

Premise2: The survey's respondents did not include people living near nuclear power plants.

On the other hand, exposure to x-rays was judged a significantly lower risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. Statement4: Psychologists have found that people tend to be more worried about risks they are not experienced than about risks they have already experienced. Statement5: Thus the survey results were probably caused by the respondents'tendency to consider not experienced risks to be greater than they actually are.

Argument: Statement1: Environmentalist : the united kingdom recently instituted a law requiring that foods containing genetically altered ingredients be labeled accordingly. Argument: Statement1: Astronomer : mount shalko is the perfect site for the proposed astronomical observatory. Statement2: The summit would accommodate the complex as currently designed, with some room left for expansion. Statement3: There are no large cities near the mountain, so neither smog nor artificial light interferes with atmospheric transparency. Statement4: Critics claim that mount shalko is a unique ecological site, but the observatory need not be a threat to endemic life-forms. Statement5: In fact, since it would preclude recreational use of the mountain, it should be their salvation. Statement6: It is estimated that 20,000 recreational users visit the mountain every year, posing a threat to the wildlife.
Premise1: Having a complex that covers most of the summit, as well as having the necessary security fences and access road on the mountain, could involve just as much ecological disruption as does the current level of recreational use.
Premise2: The building of the observatory would not cause the small towns near mount shalko eventually to develop into a large city, complete with smog, bright lights, and an influx of recreation seekers.

Statement2: The summit would accommodate the complex as currently designed, with some room left for expansion. Statement3: There are large cities near the mountain, so smog or artificial light interferes with atmospheric transparency. Statement4: Critics claim that mount shalko is a unique ecological site, but the observatory need not be a threat to endemic life-forms. Argument: Statement1: One of the most important events for modern astronomy was the series of collisions, during a single week in 1994, of more than a dozen large objects with jupiter. Statement2: The collision of these objects, which once formed most of the comet shoemaker-levy 9, resulted in formations that showed no signs of water. Statement3: There was thus no water involved in the collisions, so we know that none of the comet's fragments penetrated to jupiter's lower atmosphere and that the comet was composed of rock rather than ice.
Premise1: If jupiter's lower atmosphere had been penetrated by the comet's fragments, the resulting formations would show signs of water.
Premise2: Comets tend to be composed largely of ice while asteroids are composed mainly of rock.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Comets tend to be composed largely of ice while asteroids are composed mainly of rock.
input_info.O: Premise1: If jupiter's lower atmosphere had been penetrated by the comet's fragments, the resulting formations would show signs of water.

Argument: Statement1: Typically during thunderstorms most lightning strikes carry a negative electric charge ; only a few carry a positive charge. Thunderstorms with unusually high proportions of positive-charge strikes tend to occur in smoky areas near forest fires. Statement2: The fact that smoke carries positively charged smoke particles into the air above a fire suggests the hypothesis that the extra positive strikes occur because of the presence of such particles in the storm clouds.
Premise1: Thunderstorms that occur in drifting clouds of smoke have extra positive-charge strikes weeks after the charge of the smoke particles has dissipated.
Premise2: A positive-charge strike is as likely to start a forest fire as a negative-charge strike is.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Typically during thunderstorms most lightning strikes carry a negative electric charge ; only a few carry a positive charge. Thunderstorms with unusually high proportions of positive-charge strikes tend to occur in smoky areas near forest fires. Statement3: The fact that smoke carries positively charged smoke particles into the air above a fire suggests the hypothesis that positive charge strike is the only reason for forest fire..

input_info.Om: Premise2: A positive-charge strike is as likely to start a forest fire as a negative-charge strike is.
input_info.O: Premise1: Thunderstorms that occur in drifting clouds of smoke have extra positive-charge strikes weeks after the charge of the smoke particles has dissipated.

Argument: Statement1: Most water companies in the united states add fluoride to tap water to help prevent cavities. Some dentists argue, however, that this practice actually causes more harm than good because people overestimate the protection afforded by the fluoride and do not take the proper steps to care for their teeth, such as brushing and flossing after every meal. Statement2: If water companies did not add fluoride, the dentists claim, people would be forced to be more active in their dental hygiene and tooth decay would decline as a result.
Premise1: Most americans are not aware that fluoride is added to tap water.
Premise2: Most americans already brush their teeth daily.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement3: The dentists claim, as long as people brush their teeth at least five times a week tooth decay would decline .

input_info.Om: Premise2: Most americans already brush their teeth daily.
input_info.O: Premise1: Most americans are not aware that fluoride is added to tap water.

Argument: Statement1: Researchers have studied the cost-effectiveness of growing halophytes -- salt-tolerant plant species -- for animal forage. Statement2: Halophytes require more water than conventional crops, but can be irrigated with seawater, and pumping seawater into farms near sea level is much cheaper than pumping freshwater from deep wells. Statement3: Thus, seawater agriculture near sea level should be cost-effective in desert regions although its yields are smaller than traditional, freshwater agriculture.
Premise1: Pumping water for irrigation is proportionally one of the largest costs involved in growing, harvesting, and distributing any forage crop for animals.
Premise2: Large research expenditures are needed to develop the strains of halophytes best suited for agricultural purposes.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Researchers have studied the cost-effectiveness of growing halophytes -- salt-tolerant plant species -- for animal forage. Statement2: Halophytes require more water than conventional crops, but can be irrigated with seawater, and pumping seawater into farms near sea level is much more expensive than pumping freshwater from deep wells. Statement3: Thus, seawater agriculture near sea level should not be cost-effective in desert regions and its yields are smaller than traditional, freshwater agriculture.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument above?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Large research expenditures are needed to develop the strains of halophytes best suited for agricultural purposes.
input_info.O: Premise1: Pumping water for irrigation is proportionally one of the largest costs involved in growing, harvesting, and distributing any forage crop for animals.

Argument: Statement1: Urban planner : when a city loses population due to migration, property taxes in that city tend to rise. Premise2: Demographers project that the population of a region that includes stonebridge will start to increase substantially within the next several years.

Argument: Statement1: In colorado subalpine meadows, nonnative dandelions co-occur with a native flower, the larkspur. Statement2: Bumblebees visit both species, creating the potential for interactions between the two species with respect to pollination. Statement3: In a recent study, researchers selected 16 plots containing both species ; all dandelions were removed from eight plots ; the remaining eight control plots were left undisturbed. Statement4: The control plots yielded significantly more larkspur seeds than the dandelion-free plots, leading the researchers to conclude that the presence of dandelions facilitates pollination ( and hence seed production ) in the native species by attracting more pollinators to the mixed plots.

Statement4: The control plots yielded significantly more larkspur seeds than the dandelion-free plots, leading the researchers to conclude that the presence of dandelions facilitates pollination ( and hence seed production ) in the native species by attracting more pollinators to the mixed plots.

Argument: Statement1: In polluted environments, dolphins gradually accumulated toxins in their body fat, and the larger the dolphin the more accumulated toxin it can tolerate. Nearly 80 percent of the toxins a female dolphin has accumulated pass into the fat-rich milk her nursing calf ingests. Statement2: Therefore, the unusually high mortality rate among dolphin calves in the industrially contaminated waters along florida's gulf coast is probably the result of their being poisoned by their mother's milk.
Premise1: The survival rate of firstborn dolphin calves in the area along florida's gulf coast is highest for those whose mothers were killed before they were weaned.
Premise2: As dolphins age, they accumulate toxins from the environment more slowly than when they were young.

output: Statement1: In polluted environments, dolphins gradually accumulated toxins in their body fat, and the older the dolphin the more accumulated toxin it can tolerate. Nearly 80 percent of the toxins a female dolphin has accumulated pass into the fat-rich milk her nursing calf ingests. Statement3: Studies show that middle-aged dolphins have the highest mortality rate than young dolphins.

input_info.Om: Premise2: As dolphins age, they accumulate toxins from the environment more slowly than when they were young.
input_info.O: Premise1: The survival rate of firstborn dolphin calves in the area along florida's gulf coast is highest for those whose mothers were killed before they were weaned.

Argument: Statement1: Advertisers are often criticized for their unscrupulous manipulation of people's tastes and wants. Statement2: There is evidence, however, that some advertisers are motivated by moral as well as financial considerations. Statement3: A particular publication decided to change its image from being a family newspaper to concentrating on sex and violence, thus appealing to a different readership. Statement4: Some advertisers withdrew their advertisements from the publication, and this must have been because they morally disapproved of publishing salacious material.
Premise1: The advertisers expected their product sales to increase if they stayed with the changed publication, but to decrease if they withdrew.
Premise2: People who generally read family newspapers are not likely to buy newspapers that concentrate on sex and violence.

Statement2: There is evidence that some advertisers are motivated only by financial considerations. Statement3: A particular publication decided to change its image from being a family newspaper to concentrating on sex and violence, thus appealing to a different readership. Statement4: Some advertisers withdrew their advertisements from the publication, and this couldn't have been because they morally disapproved of publishing salacious material. It's because the current audience of newspapers does not fit their positioning as the buyer of the product.

input_info.Om: Premise2: People who generally read family newspapers are not likely to buy newspapers that concentrate on sex and violence.
input_info.O: Premise1: The advertisers expected their product sales to increase if they stayed with the changed publication, but to decrease if they withdrew.

Argument: Statement1: The average temperature of the lobster-rich waters off the coast of foerkland has been increasing for some years. Statement2: In warmer water, lobsters grow faster. Statement3: In particular, lobster larvae take less time to reach the size at which they are no longer vulnerable to predation by young cod, the chief threat to their survival. Statement4: Consequently, the survival rate of lobster larvae must be going up, and the lobster population in foerkland's coastal waters is bound to increase.
Premise1: Because of their speeded-up growth, lobsters now get large enough to be legal catch before they reach reproductive maturity.
Premise2: There are indications that in recent years the fishing fleet operating off the coast of foerkland has been taking cod at an unsustainably high rate.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The average temperature of the lobster-rich waters near the north of the coast of foerkland has been increasing for some years. Statement2: In warmer water, lobsters grow slower. Statement3: In particular, lobster larvae take more time to reach the size at which they are no longer vulnerable to predation by young cod, the chief threat to their survival. Statement4: Consequently, the survival rate of lobster larvae must be going down, and the lobster population in foerkland's coastal waters is bound to decrease.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: There are indications that in recent years the fishing fleet operating off the coast of foerkland has been taking cod at an unsustainably high rate.

Statement3: In particular, lobster larvae take less time to reach the size at which they are no longer vulnerable to predation by young cod, the chief threat to their survival. Statement4: Consequently, the survival rate of lobster larvae must be going up, and the lobster population in foerkland's coastal waters is bound to increase.

Argument: Statement1: The manager of a nuclear power plant defended the claim that the plant was safe by revealing its rate of injury for current workers : only 3.2 injuries per 200,000 hours of work, a rate less than half the national average for all industrial plants. Statement2: The manager claimed that, therefore, by the standard of how many injuries occur, the plant was safer than most other plants where the employees could work.

Premise2: The exposure of the workers to radiation at nuclear power plants was within levels the government considers safe.

Argument: Statement1: It is said that people should accept themselves as they are instead of being dissatisfied with their own abilities. Argument: Statement1: Exposure to certain chemicals commonly used in elementary schools as cleaners or pesticides causes allergic reactions in some children. Premise2: Children who are allergic to the chemicals are no more likely than other children to have allergies to other substances.

Statement2: Elementary school nurses in renston report that the proportion of schoolchildren sent to them for treatment of allergic reactions has increased significantly over the past ten years. Argument: Statement1: Shy adolescents often devote themselves totally to a hobby to help distract them from the loneliness brought on by their shyness. Statement2: Sometimes they are able to become friends with others who share their hobby. Statement3: But if they lose interest in that hobby, their loneliness may be exacerbated. Statement4: So developing an all-consuming hobby is not a successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness.
Premise1: No successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness ever intensifies that loneliness.
Premise2: Shy adolescents devote themselves to hobbies mainly because they want to make friends.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Shy adolescents often devote themselves totally to a hobby to help distract them from the loneliness brought on by their shyness. Statement2: Always they are able to become friends with others who share their hobby .they may lose interest in the hobby after making friends. Statement3: Even though they lose interest in that hobby, their loneliness won't be exacerbated. Statement4: So developing an all-consuming hobby is a successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following assumptions does the argument depend on?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Shy adolescents devote themselves to hobbies mainly because they want to make friends.
input_info.O: Premise1: No successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness ever intensifies that loneliness.
input_info.P: Statement1: Shy adolescents often devote themselves totally to a hobby to help distract them from the loneliness brought on by their shyness. Statement2: Sometimes they are able to become friends with others who share their hobby. Statement3: But if they lose interest in that hobby, their loneliness may be exacerbated. Statement4: So developing an all-consuming hobby is not a successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness.

Argument: Statement1: Ten years ago, the salisbury city council passed the culinary bill, new legislation to protect the interests of local non-franchise restaurants. Statement2: Of the 120 local non-franchise restaurants in salisbury today, 85 opened during the last ten years .those restaurants don't include non-franchise restaurants that closed a decade ago. Statement3: Clearly the culinary bill has caused a surge in the number of local non-franchise restaurants operating in salisbury over the past ten years. But restaurants that were members of national franchise chains have closed many.

Argument: Statement1: The high cost of production is severely limiting which operas are available to the public. Statement2: These costs necessitate reliance on large corporate sponsors, who in return demand that only the most famous operas be produced. Determining which operas will be produced should rest only with ticket purchasers at the box office, not with large corporate sponsors. Statement3: If we reduce production budgets so that operas can be supported exclusively by box-office receipts and donations from individuals, then the public will be able to see less famous operas.
Premise1: Without the support of large corporate sponsors, opera companies could not afford to produce any but the most famous of operas.
Premise2: Large corporate sponsors will stop supporting opera productions if they are denied control over which operas will be produced.

Argument: Statement1: Bacteria that benefit human beings when they are present in the body are called commensals. Statement2: The bacterium helicobacter pylori plays a primary role in the development of stomach ulcers. Statement3: But since stomach ulcers occur in less than 10 percent of those harboring h. pylori, and since it allegedly strengthens immune response, many scientists now consider it a commensal. But this is surely misguided. Statement4: Only about 10 percent of the people who harbor mycobacter tuberculosis -- a bacterium that can cause tuberculosis -- get sick from it, yet no one would call m. tuberculosis a commensal.
Premise1: People who harbor m. tuberculosis derive no benefit from its presence.
Premise2: There are more people who harbor m. tuberculosis than people who harbor h. pylori.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Bacteria that benefit human beings when they are present in the body not harbored by many people are called commensals. Statement2: The bacterium helicobacter pylori plays a primary role in the development of stomach ulcers. Statement3: But since stomach ulcers occur in less than 10 percent of those harboring h. pylori, and since it allegedly strengthens immune response, many scientists now consider it a commensal. But this is surely misguided. Statement5: The people who harbor mycobacter tuberculosis -- a bacterium that can cause tuberculosis -- get benefits from it, yet no one would call m. tuberculosis a commensal.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the argument's reasoning?
input_info.Om: Premise2: There are more people who harbor m. tuberculosis than people who harbor h. pylori.
input_info.O: Premise1: People who harbor m. tuberculosis derive no benefit from its presence.
input_info.P: Statement1: Bacteria that benefit human beings when they are present in the body are called commensals. Statement2: The bacterium helicobacter pylori plays a primary role in the development of stomach ulcers. Statement3: But since stomach ulcers occur in less than 10 percent of those harboring h. pylori, and since it allegedly strengthens immune response, many scientists now consider it a commensal. But this is surely misguided. Statement4: Only about 10 percent of the people who harbor mycobacter tuberculosis -- a bacterium that can cause tuberculosis -- get sick from it, yet no one would call m. tuberculosis a commensal.

Argument: Statement1: Psychologists observing a shopping mall parking lot found that, on average, drivers spent 39 seconds leaving a parking space when another car was quietly waiting to enter it, 51 seconds if the driver of the waiting car honked impatiently, but only 32 seconds leaving a space when no one was waiting. Statement2: This suggests that drivers feel possessive of their parking spaces even when leaving them, and that this possessiveness increases in reaction to indications that another driver wants the space.
Premise1: The more pressure most drivers feel because others are waiting for them to perform maneuvers with their cars, the less quickly they are able to perform them.
Premise2: The amount of time drivers spend entering a parking space is not noticeably affected by whether other drivers are waiting for them to do so, nor by whether those other drivers are honking impatiently.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Psychologists observing a shopping mall parking lot found that, on average, drivers spent 39 seconds leaving a parking space when another car was quietly waiting to enter it, 51 seconds if the driver of the waiting car honked impatiently, but only 32 seconds leaving a space when no one was waiting. Statement2: This suggests that as leaving a parking space, drivers are affected by another driver who is waiting for them when entering it.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the reasoning?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The amount of time drivers spend entering a parking space is not noticeably affected by whether other drivers are waiting for them to do so, nor by whether those other drivers are honking impatiently.
input_info.O: Premise1: The more pressure most drivers feel because others are waiting for them to perform maneuvers with their cars, the less quickly they are able to perform them.
input_info.P: Statement1: Psychologists observing a shopping mall parking lot found that, on average, drivers spent 39 seconds leaving a parking space when another car was quietly waiting to enter it, 51 seconds if the driver of the waiting car honked impatiently, but only 32 seconds leaving a space when no one was waiting. Argument: Statement1: Giordano bruno, the renaissance philosopher, must have been a spy for england during the time he served in the french embassy there. Statement2: English state records show that a spy who foiled at least two assassination plots against queen elizabeth of england was in place in the french embassy in london at that time. Premise1: Long before his employment at the embassy, bruno had been excommunicated from his church and thereafter neither dressed nor functioned as a member of the clergy.
Premise2: During the renaissance, well-educated members of the clergy often served in nonclerical roles as tutors, secretaries, and personal assistants to wealthy aristocrats.

Since the spy is identified in confidential english state documents only as" the only clergyman working at the french embassy" at that time, bruno can't have been the spy : bruno was a tutor to a wealthy duke long before he started work at the french embassy.

Argument: Statement1: Currently, warm-blooded pets are allowed to enter the country only if they have a certificate showing that they have been vaccinated against rabies. This policy is flawed because vaccinations sometimes fail to take effect. Statement2: If the vaccination is successful, the animal has a high level of rabies antibodies in its blood. Statement3: Therefore, a more effective means of preventing pets with rabies from entering the country would be to administer blood tests and refuse entry to any pets whose blood did not contain a high level of rabies antibodies.
Premise1: There is no way to distinguish between high antibody levels caused by active infection and high levels caused by successful immunization.
Premise2: The proposed policy would be ineffective in preventing wild animals infected with rabies from entering the country.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Currently, warm-blooded animals are allowed to enter the country only if they have a certificate showing that they have been vaccinated against rabies. This policy is flawed because vaccinations sometimes fail to take effect. Statement3: If the vaccination is successful, the animal has a high level of rabies antibodies in its blood and a clear and easily identifiable imprint will be left at the site of inoculation.animals that have been successfully vaccinated will not be reinfected with rabies. Statement4: Therefore, a more effective means of preventing animals with rabies from entering the country would be to administer blood tests and refuse entry to any animals whose blood did not contain a high level of rabies antibodies.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most substantially weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The proposed policy would be ineffective in preventing wild animals infected with rabies from entering the country.
input_info.O: Premise1: There is no way to distinguish between high antibody levels caused by active infection and high levels caused by successful immunization.

This policy is flawed because vaccinations sometimes fail to take effect. Statement2: If the vaccination is successful, the animal has a high level of rabies antibodies in its blood. Statement3: Therefore, a more effective means of preventing pets with rabies from entering the country would be to administer blood tests and refuse entry to any pets whose blood did not contain a high level of rabies antibodies.

Argument: Statement1: Sanderson intentionally did not tell his cousin about overhearing someone say that the factory would close, knowing that if he withheld this information, his cousin would assume it would remain open. Clearly this was morally wrong. Statement2: After all, lying is morally wrong. And making a statement with the intention of misleading someone is lying. Statement3: True, it was sanderson's failing to state something that misled his cousin. Statement4: Yet there is no moral difference between stating and failing to state if they are done with the same intention.
Premise1: Sanderson believed that the factory would in fact be closing.
Premise2: Sanderson had something to gain by his cousin's continuing to believe that the factory would remain open.

Please write the modified argument below:

Clearly this was morally wrong. Statement3: After all, lying is morally wrong. And making a statement with the intention of misleading someone and profit from it is lying. Statement5: True, it was sanderson's failing to state something that misled his cousin. Statement6: Yet there is no moral difference between stating and failing to state if they are done with the same intention.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Sanderson had something to gain by his cousin's continuing to believe that the factory would remain open.
input_info.O: Premise1: Sanderson believed that the factory would in fact be closing.

Clearly this was morally wrong. Statement2: After all, lying is morally wrong. And making a statement with the intention of misleading someone is lying. Statement3: True, it was sanderson's failing to state something that misled his cousin. Statement4: Yet there is no moral difference between stating and failing to state if they are done with the same intention.

Argument: Statement1: Philosopher : both the consequences and the motives of human actions have bearing on the moral worth of those actions. Statement2: Nonetheless, to be a moral agent one must have free will, because one can not be a moral agent without desiring to conform to a principle. 
Premise1: Desiring to conform to a principle requires free will 
Premise2: It is impossible to have desires without also being a moral agent

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: Philosopher : both the consequences and the motives of human actions have bearing on the moral worth of those actions. Statement2: Nonetheless, one can not have desires without desiring to conform to a principle, because one can not be a moral agent without desiring to conform to a principle.

Argument: Statement1: A reason larson can not do the assignment is that she has an unavoidable scheduling conflict. Statement2: On the other hand, a reason franks can not do the assignment is that he does not quite have the assertiveness the task requires. Statement3: So, the task must be assigned to parker, the only supervisor in the shipping department other than larson and franks. 
Premise1: The task cannot be assigned to anyone other than a supervisor in the shipping department. 
Premise2: The task cannot be assigned to anyone who has any kind of scheduling conflict.

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: A reason larson can not do the assignment is that she has an unavoidable scheduling conflict. Statement2: On the other hand, a reason franks can not do the assignment is that he does not quite have the assertiveness the task requires. Statement3: So, the task must be assigned to parker, the only one who do not have scheduling conflict in the shipping department other than larson and franks.

Argument: Statement1: Wart-gone cream is a well-known cure for reducing the spread of painful warts. A dime size amount rubbed on the infected area daily is the prescribed dosage, and applying the cream more often does not enhance the cream's healing effects. Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will not boost sales and, therefore, will not increase profits either. 
Premise1: The $3. 00 coupons, if distributed, would not induce new customers, who might not have purchased the product otherwise, to try wart-gone. 
Premise2: Wart-gone can be produced in small or large batches without appreciably lowering the pre-tube production costs.

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: Wart-gone cream is a well-known cure for reducing the spread of painful warts. A dime size amount rubbed on the infected area daily is the prescribed dosage, and applying the cream more often can enhance the cream's healing effects. Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will boost produce and, however, will not change pre-tube production costs much.

Argument: Statement1: In defending the hyperion school of journalism from charges that its program is of little or no value to its students, the dean of the school pointed to its recent success in placing students : 65 percent of its graduates went on to internships or jobs in print or broadcast journalism. 
Premise1: More than half of the school's students came from jobs in journalism to improve their skills. 
Premise2: Some newspaper editors do not regard journalism schools as a necessary part of the training of a journalist.

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: In defending the hyperion school of journalism from charges that its program is of little or no value to its students, the dean of the school pointed to its recent success in placing students : the journalism regards journalism schools as a necessary part of the training of a journalist.

Argument: Statement1: Several years ago, the number of wood bison became so low that conservationists began breeding the wood bison in an enclosed refuge. In this time, the number of wood bison has tripled and, according to conservationists, this number is enough for a species to remain viable in the wild. Statement2: Yet since the wood bison 's habitat is still imperiled, conservationists plan to move the wood bison 2,000 miles away, where the american buffalo, a distinct species, flourishes. Statement3: The conservationists predict that such a plan will allow for the long-term viability of the wood bison as a species.
Premise1: The american buffalo and the wood bison readily mingle, and, in the past, this has lead the two species to mix so that the number of actual wood bison declines steadily.
Premise2: The american buffalo and the wood bison can thrive off of the same resources.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Several years ago, the number of wood bison became so low that conservationists began breeding the wood bison in an enclosed refuge. In this time, the number of wood bison has tripled and, according to conservationists, this number is enough for a species to remain viable in the wild. Statement3: Yet since the wood bison 's habitat is still imperiled, conservationists plan to move the wood bison 2,000 miles away, where the american buffalo, a distinct species, flourishes. Statement4: But the conservationists predict that such a plan will not allow for the long-term viability of the wood bison as a species because the wood bison may not adapt to the new place.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, calls into question the conservationist's prediction?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The american buffalo and the wood bison can thrive off of the same resources.
input_info.O: Premise1: The american buffalo and the wood bison readily mingle, and, in the past, this has lead the two species to mix so that the number of actual wood bison declines steadily.
input_info.P: Statement1: Several years ago, the number of wood bison became so low that conservationists began breeding the wood bison in an enclosed refuge. In this time, the number of wood bison has tripled and, according to conservationists, this number is enough for a species to remain viable in the wild. Statement2: Yet since the wood bison 's habitat is still imperiled, conservationists plan to move the wood bison 2,000 miles away, where the american buffalo, a distinct species, flourishes. Statement3: The conservationists predict that such a plan will allow for the long-term viability of the wood bison as a species.

Argument: Statement1: Editorial : the threat of harsh punishment for a transgression usually decreases one's tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing that transgression, and the tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing a transgression reduces a person's tendency to commit transgressions. Statement2: Thus, increasing the severity of the legal penalties for transgressions may amplify people's tendency to ignore the welfare of others.

Premise2: Everyone has at least some tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing extremely severe transgressions.

Statement2: Thus, increasing the severity of the legal penalties for transgressions may amplify people's tendency to make extremely severe transgressions.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Everyone has at least some tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing extremely severe transgressions.
input_info.O: Premise1: At least some actions that involve ignoring the welfare of others are transgressions.
input_info.P: Statement1: Editorial : the threat of harsh punishment for a transgression usually decreases one's tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing that transgression, and the tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing a transgression reduces a person's tendency to commit transgressions. Argument: Statement1: Editorial : to qualify as an effective law, as opposed to merely an impressive declaration, a command must be backed up by an effective enforcement mechanism. Statement4: Hence, what is called" international law" is not effective law.
Premise1: Only an international police force could effectively enforce international law.
Premise2: The only difference between international law and the law of an individual society is the former's lack of an effective enforcement mechanism.

But there is currently no international effective enforcement mechanism. Statement5: Hence, what is called" international law" is not effective law.

Argument: Statement1: Astronomer : most stars are born in groups of thousands, each star in a group forming from the same parent cloud of gas. Statement2: Each cloud has a unique, homogeneous chemical composition. Statement3: Therefore, whenever two stars have the same chemical composition as each other, they must have originated from the same cloud of gas.
Premise1: Whenever a star forms, it inherits the chemical composition of its parent cloud of gas.
Premise2: Clouds of gas of similar or identical chemical composition may be remote from each other.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Astronomer : most stars are born in groups of thousands, each star in a group forming from the same parent cloud of gas. Statement2: Each cloud has a unique, homogeneous chemical composition. Statement3: However, even if two stars have the same chemical composition as each other, they may not have originated from the same cloud of gas.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, would most strengthen the astronomer's argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Clouds of gas of similar or identical chemical composition may be remote from each other.
input_info.O: Premise1: Whenever a star forms, it inherits the chemical composition of its parent cloud of gas.
input_info.P: Statement1: Astronomer : most stars are born in groups of thousands, each star in a group forming from the same parent cloud of gas. Statement2: Each cloud has a unique, homogeneous chemical composition. Statement3: Therefore, whenever two stars have the same chemical composition as each other, they must have originated from the same cloud of gas.

Argument: Statement1: Satellite navigation systems ( satnavs ) for cars, in which computer voices announce directions as you drive, save fuel and promote safety. Statement2: Studies show that, when assigned to novel destinations, drivers using satnavs took, on average, 7 percent fewer miles per journey than drivers using paper maps. Premise1: Drivers who are given directions as needed are less likely to change course suddenly or make other risky maneuvers.
Premise2: The more fuel a vehicle consumes, the more motivation a driver has to find the shortest route to his or her destination.

Argument: Statement1: Researcher : a number of studies have suggested that, on average, clients in short-term psychotherapy show similar levels of improvement regardless of the kind of psychotherapy they receive. Statement2: So any client improvement in short-term psychotherapy must be the result of some aspect or aspects of therapy that are common to all psychotherapies -- for example, the presence of someone who listens and gives attention to the client.
Premise1: The methods by which the studies measured whether clients improved primarily concerned immediate symptom relief and failed to address other important kinds of improvement.
Premise2: On average, clients improve more dramatically when they receive long-term psychotherapy, a year or longer in duration, than when clients receive short-term psychotherapy.

input_info.Om: Premise2: On average, clients improve more dramatically when they receive long-term psychotherapy, a year or longer in duration, than when clients receive short-term psychotherapy.
input_info.O: Premise1: The methods by which the studies measured whether clients improved primarily concerned immediate symptom relief and failed to address other important kinds of improvement.
input_info.P: Statement1: Researcher : a number of studies have suggested that, on average, clients in short-term psychotherapy show similar levels of improvement regardless of the kind of psychotherapy they receive. Argument: Statement1: Being articulate has been equated with having a large vocabulary. Actually, however, people with large vocabularies have no incentive for, and tend not to engage in, the kind of creative linguistic self-expression that is required when no available words seem adequate. Statement2: Thus a large vocabulary is a hindrance to using language in a truly articulate way.
Premise1: When people are truly articulate, they have the capacity to express themselves in situations in which their vocabularies seem inadequate.
Premise2: The most articulate people are people who have large vocabularies but also are able to express themselves creatively when the situation demands it.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Being articulate has been equated with having a large vocabulary. Actually, , people with large vocabularies have incentive for, and tend to engage in, the kind of creative linguistic self-expression that is required when available words seem adequate. Statement3: Thus a large vocabulary is not a hindrance to using language in a truly articulate way.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption made in the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The most articulate people are people who have large vocabularies but also are able to express themselves creatively when the situation demands it.
input_info.O: Premise1: When people are truly articulate, they have the capacity to express themselves in situations in which their vocabularies seem inadequate.
input_info.P: Statement1: Being articulate has been equated with having a large vocabulary. Actually, however, people with large vocabularies have no incentive for, and tend not to engage in, the kind of creative linguistic self-expression that is required when no available words seem adequate. Statement2: Thus a large vocabulary is a hindrance to using language in a truly articulate way.

Argument: Statement1: The more television children watch, the less competent they are in mathematical knowledge. Statement2: More than a third of children in the united states watch television for more than five hours a day ; in south korea the figure is only 7 percent. Statement3: Therefore, if united states children are to do well in mathematics, they must watch less television.

Premise2: A child's ability in advanced measurement and geometry increases if he or she watches less than one hour of television a day.
