Argument: Statement1: Market research traditionally entails surveying consumers about why they buy and use particular products and brands. Statement2: Observational research -- actually watching consumers shopping and interacting with products -- is now increasingly used by market researchers to supplement surveys. Statement3: Market researchers claim that observational research yields information about consumer behavior that surveys alone can not provide.
Premise1: Even consumers who are unable to explain their preference for or rejection of particular brands reveal which brands they are considering by picking up and putting down products while they are shopping.
Premise2: Consumers are more likely to respond to oral surveys than they are to respond to written questionnaires.

Statement2: Observational research -- actually watching consumers shopping and interacting with products -- is now increasingly used by market researchers to supplement surveys. Statement3: Market researchers claim that observational research yields information form oral surveys about consumer behavior that written questionnaires alone can not provide.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, provides the strongest support for the market researchers' claim?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Consumers are more likely to respond to oral surveys than they are to respond to written questionnaires.

Statement2: Observational research -- actually watching consumers shopping and interacting with products -- is now increasingly used by market researchers to supplement surveys. Argument: Statement1: Teresa : if their goal is to maximize profits, film studios should concentrate on producing bigbudget films rather than small-budget ones. Statement2: For, unlike big-budget films, small-budget films never attract mass audiences. Statement3: While small-budget films are less expensive to produce and, hence, involve less risk of unprofitability than big-budget films, low production costs do not guarantee the highest possible profits.

Premise2: Each big-budget film is guaranteed to attract a mass audience.

Statement2: For, unlike big-budget films, small-budget films never attract mass audiences. Statement3: While small-budget films are less expensive to produce and, hence, involve less risk of unprofitability than big-budget films, low production costs do not guarantee the audience.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Each big-budget film is guaranteed to attract a mass audience.
input_info.O: Premise1: A film studio will not maximize its profits unless at least some of its films attract mass audiences.
input_info.P: Statement1: Teresa : if their goal is to maximize profits, film studios should concentrate on producing bigbudget films rather than small-budget ones. Argument: Statement1: Zoologist : every domesticated large mammal species now in existence was domesticated thousands of years ago. Statement2: Since those days, people undoubtedly tried innumerable times to domesticate each of the wild large mammal species that seemed worth domesticating. Statement3: Clearly, therefore, most wild large mammal species in existence today either would be difficult to domesticate or would not be worth domesticating.
Premise1: It is not much easier today to domesticate wild large mammal species than it was in the past
Premise2: Of all the domesticated large mammal species in existence today, the very first to be domesticated were the easiest to domesticate

Statement3: Clearly, therefore, most domesticated large mammal species in existence today either would be easy to domesticate or would be worth domesticating.

input_info.O: Premise1: It is not much easier today to domesticate wild large mammal species than it was in the past

input_info.Om: Premise2: Public opinion does not determine the artistic value of a work of art.

Argument: Statement1: Purebred dogs are prone to genetically determined abnormalities. Although such abnormalities often can be corrected by surgery, the cost can reach several thousand dollars. Statement2: Since nonpurebred dogs rarely suffer from genetically determined abnormalities, potential dog owners who want to reduce the risk of incurring costly medical bills for their pets would be well advised to choose nonpurebred dogs.
Premise1: Most genetically determined abnormalities in dogs do not seriously affect a dog's general well-being.
Premise2: A dog that does not have genetically determined abnormalities may nevertheless have offspring with such abnormalities.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Purebred dogs are prone to genetically determined abnormalities. Although such abnormalities often can be corrected by surgery, the cost can reach several thousand dollars. Statement3: Since nonpurebred dogs rarely suffer from genetically determined abnormalities, potential dog owners who want to reduce the risk of incurring costly medical bills for their pets would be well advised to choose nonpurebred dogs' offspring.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: A dog that does not have genetically determined abnormalities may nevertheless have offspring with such abnormalities.
input_info.O: Premise1: Most genetically determined abnormalities in dogs do not seriously affect a dog's general well-being.

Argument: Statement1: Some species of arctic birds are threatened by recent sharp increases in the population of snow geese, which breed in the arctic and are displacing birds of less vigorous species. Although snow geese are a popular quarry for hunters in the southern regions where they winter, the hunting season ends if and when hunting has reduced the population by five percent, according to official estimates. Statement2: Clearly, dropping this restriction would allow the other species to recover.
Premise1: It has been many years since the restriction led to the hunting season for snow geese being closed earlier than the scheduled date.
Premise2: The number of snow geese taken by hunters each year has grown every year for several years.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Some species of arctic birds are threatened by recent sharp increases in the population of snow geese, which breed in the arctic and are displacing birds of less vigorous species. Although snow geese are a popular quarry for hunters in the southern regions where they winter, the hunting season ends if and when hunting has reduced the population by five percent, according to official estimates. Statement3: Clearly, dropping this restriction wouldn't allow the other species to recover.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The number of snow geese taken by hunters each year has grown every year for several years.
input_info.O: Premise1: It has been many years since the restriction led to the hunting season for snow geese being closed earlier than the scheduled date.

Statement2: Clearly, dropping this restriction would allow the other species to recover.

Argument: Statement1: Fossil-fuel producers say that it would be prohibitively expensive to reduce levels of carbon dioxide emitted by the use of fossil fuels enough to halt global warming. This claim is probably false. Statement2: Several years ago, the chemical industry said that finding an economical alternative to the chlorofluorocarbons ( cfcs ) destroying the ozone layer would be impossible. Yet once the industry was forced, by international agreements, to find substitutes for cfcs, it managed to phase them out completely well before the mandated deadline, in many cases at a profit.
Premise1: There are ways of reducing carbon dioxide emissions that could halt global warming without hurting profits of fossil-fuel producers significantly more than phasing out cfcs hurt those of the chemical industry.
Premise2: The use of cfcs never contributed as greatly to the destruction of the ozone layer as the carbon dioxide emitted by the use of fossil fuels currently contributes to global warming.

Statement3: Several years ago, although the chemical industry said that finding an economical alternative to the chlorofluorocarbons ( cfcs ) destroying the ozone layer would be impossible. Argument: Statement1: The gray squirrel, introduced into local woodlands ten years ago, threatens the indigenous population of an endangered owl species, because the squirrels'habitual stripping of tree bark destroys the trees in which the owls nest. Statement2: Some local officials have advocated setting out poison for the gray squirrels. The officials argue that this measure, while eliminating the squirrels, would pose no threat to the owl population, since the poison would be placed in containers accessible only to squirrels and other rodents.
Premise1: The owls whose nesting sites are currently being destroyed by the gray squirrels feed primarily on rodents.
Premise2: No indigenous population of any other bird species apart from the endangered owls is threatened by the gray squirrels.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The gray squirrel, introduced into local woodlands ten years ago, threatens the indigenous population of an endangered owl species, because the squirrels'habitual stripping of tree bark destroys the trees in which the owls nest. Statement2: Some local officials have advocated setting out poison for the gray squirrels. The officials argue that this measure, while eliminating the squirrels, would increase the indigenous population of other bird species.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most calls into question the officials' argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: No indigenous population of any other bird species apart from the endangered owls is threatened by the gray squirrels.
input_info.O: Premise1: The owls whose nesting sites are currently being destroyed by the gray squirrels feed primarily on rodents.

Argument: Statement1: When permits for the discharge of chemicals into a waterway are issued, they are issued in terms of the number of pounds of each chemical that can be discharged into the waterway per day. These figures, calculated separately for each chemical for which a permit is issued, are based on an estimate of the effect of the dilution of the chemical by the amount of water flowing through the waterway. Statement2: The waterway is therefore protected against being adversely affected by chemicals discharged under the permits.

Premise2: There are no chemicals for which discharge into waterways is entirely prohibited

Argument: Statement1: In an experiment, researchers played a series of musical intervals -- two-note sequences -- to a large, diverse group of six-month-old babies. They found that the babies paid significantly more attention when the intervals were perfect octaves, fifths, or fourths than otherwise. These intervals are prevalent in the musical systems of most cultures around the world. Statement2: Thus, humans probably have a biological predisposition to pay more attention to those intervals than to others.
Premise1: None of the babies in the experiment had previous exposure to music from any culture.
Premise2: Several similar experiments using older children and adults found that these subjects, too, had a general tendency to pay more attention to octaves, fifths, and fourths than to other musical intervals.

These intervals are prevalent in the musical systems of most cultures around the world. Statement4: Thus, humans regardless of age, probably have a biological predisposition to pay more attention to those intervals than to others.

input_info.O: Premise1: None of the babies in the experiment had previous exposure to music from any culture.

Argument: Statement1: The economy around lake paqua depends on fishing of the lake's landlocked salmon population. Statement2: In recent years, scarcity of food for salmon there has caused a decline in both the number and the size of the adult salmon in the lake. Statement4: To remedy this situation, officials plan to introduce shrimp, which can serve as a food source for adult salmon, into lake paqua.

Premise2: The shrimp to be introduced into lake paqua are of a variety that is too small to be harvested for human consumption.

input_info.P: Statement1: The laboratory experiment, the most effective method for teaching science, is disappearing from most secondary school curricula, and students are now simulating experiments with computers. Statement2: This trend should be stopped. It results in many students'completing secondary school and going on to a university without knowing how to work with laboratory equipment.

Argument: Statement1: Many industrialized nations are trying to reduce atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, a gas released by the burning of fossil fuels. Statement2: One proposal is to replace conventional cement, which is made with calcium carbonate, by a new" eco-cement. " Statement3: This new cement, made with magnesium carbonate, absorbs large amount of carbon dioxide when exposed to the atmosphere. Statement4: Therefore, using eco-cement for new concrete building projects will significantly help reduce atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide.
Premise1: The manufacture of eco-cement uses considerably less fossil fuel per unit of cement than the manufacture of conventional cement does.
Premise2: Eco-cement is strengthened when absorbed carbon dioxide reacts with the cement.

Statement4: Therefore, using eco-cement for new concrete building projects will significantly help improve the quality of concrete building.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Eco-cement is strengthened when absorbed carbon dioxide reacts with the cement.
input_info.O: Premise1: The manufacture of eco-cement uses considerably less fossil fuel per unit of cement than the manufacture of conventional cement does.

Argument: Statement1: Two centuries ago, tufe peninsula became separated from the mainland, isolating on the newly formed tufe island a population of turfil sunflowers. Statement3: So the current average height of tufe's turfil sunflowers is undoubtedly at least partially attributable to changes in tufe's environmental conditions.

Argument: Statement1: The average hourly wage of television assemblers in vernland has long been significantly lower than that in neighboring borodia. Statement2: Since borodia dropped all tariffs on vernlandian televisions three years ago, the number of televisions sold annually in borodia has not changed. However, recent statistics show a drop in the number of television assemblers in borodia. Statement3: Therefore, updated trade statistics will probably indicate that the number of televisions borodia imports annually from vernland has increased.
Premise1: The average number of hours it takes a borodian television assembler to assemble a television has not decreased significantly during the past three years
Premise2: The number of television assemblers in vernland has increased by at least as much as the number of television assemblers in borodia has decreased

However, recent statistics show a drop in the number of television assemblers in borodia. Statement4: Therefore, updated trade statistics will probably indicate that thetelevision assembers have gone to vernland.

Argument: Statement1: Juries in criminal trials do not base verdicts on uncorroborated testimony given by any one witness. Rightly so, because it is usually prudent to be highly skeptical of unsubstantiated claims made by any one person. Statement2: But then, to be consistent, juries should end an all-too-common practice : convicting defendants on the basis of an uncorroborated full confession.
Premise1: Highly suggestible people who are accused of wrongdoing sometimes become so unsure of their own recollection of the past that they can come to accept the accusations made against them.
Premise2: Defendants sometimes make full confessions when they did in fact do what they are accused of doing and have come to believe that the prosecutor has compelling proof of this.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Juries in criminal trials do not base verdicts on uncorroborated testimony given by any one witness. Rightly so, because it is usually prudent to be highly skeptical of unsubstantiated claims made by any one person. Statement3: But then, to be consistent, juries should adopt an all-too-common practice : convicting defendants on the basis of an uncorroborated full confession.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Defendants sometimes make full confessions when they did in fact do what they are accused of doing and have come to believe that the prosecutor has compelling proof of this.

Argument: Statement1: A physician who is too thorough in conducting a medical checkup is likely to subject the patient to the discomfort and expense of unnecessary tests. Statement2: One who is not thorough enough is likely to miss some serious problem and therefore give the patient a false sense of security. It is difficult for physicians to judge exactly how thorough they should be. Statement3: Therefore, it is generally unwise for patients to have medical checkups when they do not feel ill.
Premise1: Some serious diseases in their early stages have symptoms that physicians can readily detect, although patients are not aware of any problem.
Premise2: Patients not medically trained are unable to judge for themselves what degree of thoroughness is appropriate for physicians in conducting medical checkups.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A physician who is too thorough in conducting a medical checkup is likely to subject the patient to the discomfort and expense of unnecessary tests. Statement2: One who is not thorough enough is likely to miss some serious problem and therefore give the patient a false sense of security. It is difficult for physicians to judge exactly how thorough they should be. Statement4: Therefore, it is generally wise for patients to determine the degree of their medical checkup.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, would most seriously weaken the argument in the passage?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Patients not medically trained are unable to judge for themselves what degree of thoroughness is appropriate for physicians in conducting medical checkups.
input_info.O: Premise1: Some serious diseases in their early stages have symptoms that physicians can readily detect, although patients are not aware of any problem.

Argument: Statement1: Ecologist : smallpox, one of the worst diseases ever to afflict humans, has in some outbreaks killed as much as 50 percent of local populations. Statement2: The last known surviving cultures of variola -- the smallpox virus -- are confined to two high-security laboratories. Some scientists are anxious to destroy the remaining variola cultures, to which humans are susceptible. Statement3: Research on the cultures, however, may someday lead to important benefits for humans, and so the cultures should not be destroyed.
Premise1: It is more likely that the virus, if left available to researchers, will lead to an important medical breakthrough than that the virus will be accidentally released from the laboratory.
Premise2: Smallpox has killed millions of humans over the centuries, and when it reaches the stage of an epidemic it is extremely difficult to eradicate.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Ecologist : smallpox, one of the worst diseases ever to afflict humans, has in some outbreaks killed as much as 50 percent of local populations. Statement2: The last known surviving cultures of variola -- the smallpox virus -- are confined to two high-security laboratories. Some scientists are anxious to destroy the remaining variola cultures, to which humans are susceptible. Statement4: Research on the cultures, although, may someday lead to important benefits for humans, the cultures should be destroyed.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, would do most to strengthen the ecologist's argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Smallpox has killed millions of humans over the centuries, and when it reaches the stage of an epidemic it is extremely difficult to eradicate.
input_info.O: Premise1: It is more likely that the virus, if left available to researchers, will lead to an important medical breakthrough than that the virus will be accidentally released from the laboratory.
input_info.P: Statement1: Ecologist : smallpox, one of the worst diseases ever to afflict humans, has in some outbreaks killed as much as 50 percent of local populations. Statement2: The last known surviving cultures of variola -- the smallpox virus -- are confined to two high-security laboratories. Some scientists are anxious to destroy the remaining variola cultures, to which humans are susceptible. Statement3: Research on the cultures, however, may someday lead to important benefits for humans, and so the cultures should not be destroyed.

Argument: Statement1: Those who participate in risky sports often do so to confront their fears. Statement2: For example, rock climbers are more likely than others to have once suffered from a fear of heights. Those who participate in such risk-taking activities also have more self-confidence than others, so it is probably true that confronting one's fears increases one's self-confidence.
Premise1: In general, people who currently participate in risky sports had above-average self-confidence even before participating in any risky sport.
Premise2: Most people who refrain from engaging in risky sports refrain from doing so for reasons other than a fear of death or injury.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: For example, rock climbers are more likely than others to have once suffered from a fear of heights. Those who participate in such risk-taking activities also have less fear of death or injury. Than others, so it is probably true that confronting one's fears increases one's self-confidence.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the reasoning above?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Most people who refrain from engaging in risky sports refrain from doing so for reasons other than a fear of death or injury.
input_info.O: Premise1: In general, people who currently participate in risky sports had above-average self-confidence even before participating in any risky sport.
input_info.P: Statement1: Those who participate in risky sports often do so to confront their fears. Statement2: For example, rock climbers are more likely than others to have once suffered from a fear of heights. Argument: Statement1: A major chemical spill occurred five years ago at baker's beach, the world's sole nesting ground for merrick sea turtles, and prevented nearly all the eggs laid that year from hatching. Yet the number of adult female merricks returning to lay their eggs at baker's beach has actually increased somewhat since five years ago. Statement2: Clearly, environmentalists'prediction that the world's merrick population would decline as a result of the spill has proven unfounded.
Premise1: Female merrick sea turtles begin returning to baker's beach to lay their eggs when they are ten years old.
Premise2: The chemical spill five years ago occurred at a time when there were neither merrick sea turtles nor merrick sea turtle eggs on baker's beach.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A major chemical spill occurred five years ago at baker's beach, the world's biggest nesting ground for merrick sea turtles, and prevented nearly all the eggs laid that year from hatching. Yet the number of five years old adult female merricks returning to lay their eggs at baker's beach has actually increased this year. Statement3: Clearly, environmentalists'prediction that the world's merrick population would decline as a result of the spill has proven unfounded.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the argument offered in refutation of the environmentalists' prediction?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The chemical spill five years ago occurred at a time when there were neither merrick sea turtles nor merrick sea turtle eggs on baker's beach.
input_info.O: Premise1: Female merrick sea turtles begin returning to baker's beach to lay their eggs when they are ten years old.
input_info.P: Statement1: A major chemical spill occurred five years ago at baker's beach, the world's sole nesting ground for merrick sea turtles, and prevented nearly all the eggs laid that year from hatching. Statement2: Clearly, environmentalists'prediction that the world's merrick population would decline as a result of the spill has proven unfounded.

Argument: Statement1: Heavy salting of albritten's roads to melt winter ice and snow began about 20 years ago. Statement2: The area's groundwater now contains approximately 100 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter. Statement3: Groundwater in a nearby, less highly urbanized area, where little salt is used and where traffic patterns resemble those of albritten 20 years ago, contains only about 10 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter. Statement4: Since water that contains 250 or more milligrams of dissolved salt per liter tastes unacceptably salty, continuing the salting of albritten's roads at its present rate will render albritten's groundwater unpalatable within the next few decades.
Premise1: Albritten's groundwater contained roughly 90 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter 20 years ago.
Premise2: Even water that contains up to 5, 000 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter is safe to drink.

Statement2: The area's groundwater now contains approximately 100 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter. Statement3: Groundwater in a nearby, less highly urbanized area, where little salt is used and where traffic patterns resemble those of albritten 20 years ago, contains only about 10 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter. Statement4: Since water that contains 250 or more milligrams of dissolved salt per liter tastes unacceptably salty, continuing the salting of albritten's roads at its present rate will render albritten's groundwater harmful to people's health.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Even water that contains up to 5, 000 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter is safe to drink.
input_info.O: Premise1: Albritten's groundwater contained roughly 90 milligrams of dissolved salt per liter 20 years ago.

Argument: Statement1: Of patients over 65 years old who survived coronary bypass surgery-a procedure widely prescribed for people with heart disease-only 75 percent benefited from the surgery. Statement2: Thus it appears that for one in four such patients, they accept surgery more out of over-confidence in the outcome of the surgery..

Argument: Statement1: Critic : political utility determines the popularity of a metaphor. In authoritarian societies, the metaphor of society as a human body governed by a head is pervasive. Statement2: Therefore, the society-as-body metaphor, with its connection between society's proper functioning and governance by a head, promotes greater acceptance of authoritarian repression than do other metaphors, such as likening society to a family.
Premise1: In authoritarian societies, the metaphor of society as a family is just as pervasive as the society-as-body metaphor.
Premise2: Authoritarian leaders are always searching for new metaphors for society in their effort to maintain their power.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Critic : political utility determines the popularity of a metaphor. In authoritarian societies, the metaphor of society as a human body governed by a head is pervasive. Statement3: Therefore, the society-as-body metaphor, with its connection between society's proper functioning and governance by a head, maybe most promotes acceptance of authoritarian repression than do other metaphors.

Argument: Statement1: Nuclear reactors are sometimes built in" geologically quiet" regions, so called by geologists because such regions are distant from plate boundaries and contain only minor faults. Statement2: Since no minor fault in a geologically quiet region produces an earthquake more often than once in any given 100,000-year period, it follows that of all potential nuclear reactor sites in such a region, those that are least likely to be struck by an earthquake are ones located near a fault that has produced an earthquake within living memory.
Premise1: In a geologically quiet region, every potential nuclear reactor site is near at least one minor fault.
Premise2: Geologically quiet regions are the least dangerous regions in which to build nuclear reactors.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: Since no minor fault in a geologically quiet region produces an earthquake more often than once in any given 100,000-year period, it follows that of all potential nuclear reactor sites in such a region, those that are least likely to be struck by an earthquake are ones located near a fault that has produced an earthquake within living memory.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Geologically quiet regions are the least dangerous regions in which to build nuclear reactors.
input_info.O: Premise1: In a geologically quiet region, every potential nuclear reactor site is near at least one minor fault.

Argument: Statement1: The sense of delayed gratification, of working now for later pleasure, has helped shape the economic behavior of our society. Statement2: However, that sense is no longer nurtured as consistently in our children as it once was. Statement3: For example, it used to take a bit of patience to put together the toys that children got in cereal boxes ; now the toys come from the boxes whole.
Premise1: The toys that used to come in cereal boxes were put together by the same children who played with them.
Premise2: The toys in cereal boxes have changed partly because the economic conditions of our society have improved.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: However, that sense is no longer nurtured as consistently in our children as it once was. Statement3: For example, it used to take a bit of patience for parents to put together the toys that children got in cereal boxes ; now the toys come from the boxes whole.

input_info.Q: Which of the following is an assumption of the passage above?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The toys in cereal boxes have changed partly because the economic conditions of our society have improved.
input_info.O: Premise1: The toys that used to come in cereal boxes were put together by the same children who played with them.
input_info.P: Statement1: The sense of delayed gratification, of working now for later pleasure, has helped shape the economic behavior of our society. Statement5: Therefore, the airlines should rethink their training approach to reducing commercial crashes.

Premise2: Commercial pilots routinely undergo additional training throughout their careers.

Statement5: Therefore, the airlines should simplify such training approach to reducing commercial crashes.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Commercial pilots routinely undergo additional training throughout their careers.
input_info.O: Premise1: Lack of actual flying time is an important contributor to pilot error in commercial plane crashes.

Statement5: Therefore, the airlines should rethink their training approach to reducing commercial crashes.

Premise2: Worker-owned businesses have traditionally obtained loans from cooperative lending institutions established by coalitions of worker-owned businesses.

Statement4: Therefore, no lending institutions would make loans to worker-owned businesses.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Worker-owned businesses have traditionally obtained loans from cooperative lending institutions established by coalitions of worker-owned businesses.
input_info.O: Premise1: In most worker-owned businesses, workers compensate for inefficiencies by working longer hours than do workers in investor-owned businesses.

Statement2: The only place where the wild form of emmer wheat has been found growing is a relatively narrow strip of southwest asia.
Premise1: In the region containing the strip where wild emmer wheat has been found, climatic conditions have changed very little since before the development of agriculture.
Premise2: It is very difficult, without genetic testing, to differentiate the wild form of emmer wheat from a closely related wild wheat that also grows in southwest asia.

Argument: Statement1: In their native habitat, amaryllis plants go dormant when the soil in which they are growing dries out during the dry season. Argument: Statement1: Economist : during a recession, a company can cut personnel costs either by laying off some employees without reducing the wages of remaining employees or by reducing the wages of all employees without laying off anyone. Statement2: Thus, when companies must reduce personnel costs during recessions, they are likely to lay off employees.
Premise1: Employee morale is usually the primary concern driving companies' decisions about whether to lay off employees or to reduce their wages.
Premise2: Some companies that have laid off employees during recessions have had difficulty finding enough qualified employees once economic growth resumed.

input_info.O: Premise1: Employee morale is usually the primary concern driving companies' decisions about whether to lay off employees or to reduce their wages.

Argument: Statement1: After an area has been hit by a natural disaster, there is often a great demand for plywood for repairing damaged homes. Statement2: Retailers in the area often raise prices on new shipments of plywood to well above their predisaster prices, and some people denounce these retailers for taking advantage of a disaster to make more money on each sheet of plywood they sell. Statement3: In fact, however, these retailers do not make more money on each sheet of plywood than before the disaster, because transporting the plywood into devastated areas is difficult and expensive, and therefore the plywood's cost to retailers is higher than it was before the disaster.
Premise1: The increase in the prices charged by retailers for plywood following a natural disaster does not exceed the increase in cost to those retailers.
Premise2: Retailers must pay the full amount of any increase in shipping costs.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: After an area has been hit by a natural disaster, there is often a great demand for plywood for repairing damaged homes. Statement2: Retailers in the area often raise prices on new shipments of plywood to well above their predisaster prices, and some people denounce these retailers for taking advantage of a disaster to make more money on each sheet of plywood they sell. Statement3: In fact, however, these retailers do not make more money on each sheet of plywood than before the disaster, because the increase fee of transporting the plywood into devastated areas is the same as the increased price, and therefore the plywood's profit to retailers is same as it was before the disaster.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Retailers must pay the full amount of any increase in shipping costs.
input_info.O: Premise1: The increase in the prices charged by retailers for plywood following a natural disaster does not exceed the increase in cost to those retailers.

Argument: Statement1: Farmer : several people in the past few years have claimed to have seen a mountain lion in the suburban outskirts-the latest just last month-and, while mountain lions were thought to have been driven from this entire region about twenty years ago, there is no reason for the people who reported seeing a mountain lion to have deliberately concocted a false report. Argument: Statement1: Albert : the government has proposed new automobile emissions regulations designed to decrease the amount of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons ( pahs ) released into the atmosphere by automobile exhaust. Premise2: It is not known whether pahs are a causal factor in any diseases other than heart and lung disease and cancer.

Statement4: Erin : scientists also blame pahs released by automobile exhaust for 10,000 premature deaths in this country each year from heart and lung disease and some other disease. Statement5: So the proposed regulations would save thousands of lives.

Premise2: It is impossible to have desires without also being a moral agent

Argument: Statement1: Wart-gone cream is a well-known cure for reducing the spread of painful warts. A dime size amount rubbed on the infected area daily is the prescribed dosage, and applying the cream more often does not enhance the cream's healing effects. Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will not boost sales and, therefore, will not increase profits either. 
Premise1: The $3. 00 coupons, if distributed, would not induce new customers, who might not have purchased the product otherwise, to try wart-gone. 
Premise2: Wart-gone can be produced in small or large batches without appreciably lowering the pre-tube production costs.

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:

A dime size amount rubbed on the infected area daily is the prescribed dosage, and applying the cream more often can enhance the cream's healing effects. Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will boost produce and, however, will not change pre-tube production costs much.

Argument: Statement1: Elephants are often observed licking clay from mud holes. There is ample evidence that other animals ingest clay because it neutralizes toxins in their diets. Statement2: Since elephants eat many plants that contain toxic compounds, their licking of clay is probably triggered by toxins too.
Premise1: Elephants do not lick clay at times when their diet consists almost entirely of toxin-free foods.
Premise2: Elephants typically drink water immediately before or after they lick clay.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Elephants are often observed licking clay from mud holes. There is ample evidence that other animals ingest clay because it neutralizes toxins in their drinking water. Statement3: Since elephants drink water that contain toxic compounds, their licking of clay is probably triggered by toxins too.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Elephants typically drink water immediately before or after they lick clay.
input_info.O: Premise1: Elephants do not lick clay at times when their diet consists almost entirely of toxin-free foods.
input_info.P: Statement1: Elephants are often observed licking clay from mud holes. There is ample evidence that other animals ingest clay because it neutralizes toxins in their diets. Statement2: Since elephants eat many plants that contain toxic compounds, their licking of clay is probably triggered by toxins too.

Argument: Statement1: Bank depositors in the united states are all financially protected against bank failure because the government insures all individuals'bank deposits. An economist argues that this insurance is partly responsible for the high rate of bank failures, since it removes from depositors any financial incentive to find out whether the bank that holds their money is secure against failure. Statement2: If depositors were more selective. Then banks would need to be secure in order to compete for depositors'money.
Premise1: When the government did not insure deposits frequent bank failures occurred as a result of depositors' fears of losing money in bank failures.
Premise2: Before the government started to insure depositors against bank failure, there was a lower rate of bank failure than there is now.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Bank depositors in the united states are all financially protected against bank failure because the government insures all individuals'bank deposits. An economist argues that this insurance is partly responsible for the low rate of bank failures, since it provides to government financial incentive to find out whether the bank that holds money is secure against failure. Statement3: If government was more selective. Then banks would need to be secure in order to compete for depositors'money.

input_info.Q: Which of he following, if true, most seriously weakens the economist s argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Before the government started to insure depositors against bank failure, there was a lower rate of bank failure than there is now.
input_info.O: Premise1: When the government did not insure deposits frequent bank failures occurred as a result of depositors' fears of losing money in bank failures.

Argument: Statement1: Many scientific studies have suggested that taking melatonin tablets can induce sleep. Statement2: But this does not mean that melatonin is helpful in treating insomnia. Statement3: Most of the studies examined only people without insomnia, and in many of the studies, only a few of the subjects given melatonin appeared to be significantly affected by it.

Argument: Statement1: In casual conversation, people experience little psychological discomfort in admitting that they have some particular character flaw, but only if they consider trivial the flaw to which they admit. Statement2: Therefore, if in a casual conversation an individual readily admits that he or she has some particular character flaw, the individual must not consider that flaw to be serious.
Premise1: In casual conversation, people readily admit to having a character flaw only when that admission causes them little psychological discomfort.
Premise2: People admit to having only those character flaws that most other people consider trivial.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: In casual conversation, people experience little psychological discomfort in admitting that they have some particular character flaw. Statement2: Therefore, if in a casual conversation an individual experiences little psychological discomfort in admiting that he or she has some particular character flaw, other people must not consider that flaw to be serious.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption necessary to the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: People admit to having only those character flaws that most other people consider trivial.
input_info.O: Premise1: In casual conversation, people readily admit to having a character flaw only when that admission causes them little psychological discomfort.
input_info.P: Statement1: In casual conversation, people experience little psychological discomfort in admitting that they have some particular character flaw, but only if they consider trivial the flaw to which they admit. Argument: Statement1: Escalating worldwide demand for corn is expected to cause the market price of corn to rise sharply and remain high. Argument: Statement1: Scientists have long thought that omega-3 fatty acids in fish oil tend to lower blood cholesterol and strongly suspected that a diet that includes a modest amount of fish would provide substantial health benefits. Premise2: The test subjects in the recent study who ate fish twice a week did not have a diet that was otherwise conducive to the development of heart disease.

Argument: Statement1: A hospital should not be entitled to patent the research breakthroughs of its resident physicians. Statement2: Hospitals, as sources of medical advancement, should encourage the free flow of ideas and the general dissemination of medical knowledge. Yet a hospital that retains the right to patent the breakthroughs of its resident physicians has a motive to suppress information about the discovery of a potentially valuable medicine until the patent for it has been secured. Statement3: Clearly, suppressing information concerning such discoveries is incompatible with the hospital's obligation to promote the general dissemination of medical knowledge.
Premise1: Hospitals that have a motive to suppress information concerning research breakthroughs by their resident physicians will occasionally act on that motive.
Premise2: Hospitals are the only institutions that have an obligation to serve as a source of medical advancement.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A hospital should not be entitled to patent the research breakthroughs of its resident physicians. Statement2: Hospitals, as sources of medical advancement, should encourage the free flow of ideas and the general dissemination of medical knowledge. Yet a hospital that retains the right to patent the breakthroughs of its resident physicians must have a motive to suppress information about the discovery of a potentially valuable medicine until the patent for it has been secured. Statement4: Clearly, suppressing information concerning such discoveries is incompatible with the institution's obligation to promote the general dissemination of medical knowledge.

Argument: Statement1: John of worcester, an english monk, recorded the sighting, on december 8, 1128, of two unusually large sunspots. Statement3: Thus, the korean sighting helps to confirm john of worcester's sighting.

Premise2: An aurora borealis can sometimes occur even when there has been no significant sunspot activity in the previous week.

input_info.Om: Premise2: An aurora borealis can sometimes occur even when there has been no significant sunspot activity in the previous week.
input_info.O: Premise1: Only heavy sunspot activity could have resulted in an aurora borealis viewable at a latitude as low as that of korea.
input_info.P: Statement1: John of worcester, an english monk, recorded the sighting, on december 8, 1128, of two unusually large sunspots. Five days later a brilliant aurora borealis ( northern lights ) was observed in southern korea. Statement2: Sunspot activity is typically followed by the appearance of an aurora borealis, after a span of time that averages five days. Statement3: Thus, the korean sighting helps to confirm john of worcester's sighting.

Argument: Statement1: Gortland has long been narrowly self-sufficient in both grain and meat. However, as per capita income in gortland has risen toward the world average, per capita consumption of meat has also risen toward the world average, and it takes several pounds of grain to produce one pound of meat. Statement2: Therefore, since per capita income continues to rise, whereas domestic grain production will not increase, gortland will soon have to import either grain or meat or both.
Premise1: People in gortland who increase their consumption of meat will not radically decrease their consumption of grain.
Premise2: The total acreage devoted to grain production in gortland will soon decrease.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Gortland has long been narrowly self-sufficient in both grain and meat. However, as per capita income in gortland has risen toward the world average, per capita consumption of meat has also risen toward the world average, and it takes half pound of grain to produce one pound of meat. Statement3: Therefore, since per capita income continues to rise, whereas domestic meat demand will increase, gortland will soon able to export meat.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The total acreage devoted to grain production in gortland will soon decrease.
input_info.O: Premise1: People in gortland who increase their consumption of meat will not radically decrease their consumption of grain.

Argument: Statement1: In modern deep-diving marine mammals, such as whales, the outer shell of the bones is porous. Statement2: This has the effect of making the bones light enough so that it is easy for the animals to swim back to the surface after a deep dive. Premise2: Some deep-diving marine species must surface after dives but do not have bones with porous outer shells.

Statement3: The outer shell of the bones was not porous in the ichthyosaur, an extinct prehistoric marine reptile. Statement4: We can conclude from this that ichthyosaurs might not be deep divers.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Some deep-diving marine species must surface after dives but do not have bones with porous outer shells.
input_info.O: Premise1: In most modern and prehistoric marine reptile species that are not deep divers, the outer shell of the bones is porous.

Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will boost produce and, however, will not change pre-tube production costs much.

Argument: Statement1: A study followed a group of teenagers who had never smoked and tracked whether they took up smoking and how their mental health changed. Statement2: After one year, the incidence of depression among those who had taken up smoking was four times as high as it was among those who had not. Statement3: Since nicotine in cigarettes changes brain chemistry, perhaps thereby affecting mood, it is likely that smoking contributes to depression in teenagers.
Premise1: Participants who were depressed at the start of the study were no more likely to be smokers after one year than those who were not depressed.
Premise2: The study did not distinguish between participants who smoked only occasionally and those who were heavy smokers.

output: Statement1: A study followed a group of teenagers who had never smoked and tracked whether they took up smoking and how their mental health changed. Statement2: After one year, the incidence of depression among those who had taken up smoking was four times as high as it was among those who had not. Statement3: Although nicotine in cigarettes changes brain chemistry, perhaps thereby affecting mood, it is not likely that smoking occasionly contributes to depression in teenagers.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The study did not distinguish between participants who smoked only occasionally and those who were heavy smokers.

Argument: Statement1: Political scientist : the dissemination of political theories is in principle able to cause change in existing social structures. Statement2: However, all political theories are formulated in the educationally privileged setting of the university, leading to convoluted language that is alienating to many individuals outside academia who would be important agents of change. Statement3: It follows that, with respect to political theory, there is a special role for those outside the university context to render it into accessible, clear language.
Premise1: Persons within academic settings are less willing or less able than persons outside to write in a straightforward way.
Premise2: Persons outside academic settings are the most important agents of change to the social structure.

Statement2: However, all political theories are formulated in the educationally privileged setting of the university, leading to convoluted language that is alienating to many individuals outside academia who would be important agents of change. Statement3: It follows that, with respect to political theory, there is a key role for those outside the university context to render it into accessible, clear language.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Persons outside academic settings are the most important agents of change to the social structure.
input_info.O: Premise1: Persons within academic settings are less willing or less able than persons outside to write in a straightforward way.

Argument: Statement1: The current pattern of human consumption of resources, in which we rely on nonrenewable resources, for example metal ore, must eventually change. Premise2: There are renewable resource replacements for all of the nonrenewable resources currently being consumed.

input_info.Om: Premise2: There are renewable resource replacements for all of the nonrenewable resources currently being consumed.

Argument: Statement1: Recently discovered prehistoric rock paintings on small islands off the northern coast of norway have archaeologists puzzled. Statement2: The predominant theory about northern cave paintings was that they were largely a description of the current diets of the painters. This theory can not be right, because the painters must have needed to eat the sea animals populating the waters north of norway if they were to make the long journey to and from the islands, and there are no paintings that unambiguously depict such creatures.
Premise1: The cave paintings that were discovered on the islands depicted many land animals.
Premise2: Parts of the cave paintings on the islands did not survive the centuries.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Recently discovered rock paintings on small islands off the northern coast of norway have archaeologists puzzled. Statement2: The predominant theory about northern cave paintings was that they were largely a description of the current diets of the painters. This theory can not be right, because the painters must have needed to eat the animals populating the north of norway if they were to make the long journey to and from the islands, and there are no paintings that unambiguously depict such creatures.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Parts of the cave paintings on the islands did not survive the centuries.
input_info.O: Premise1: The cave paintings that were discovered on the islands depicted many land animals.
input_info.P: Statement1: Recently discovered prehistoric rock paintings on small islands off the northern coast of norway have archaeologists puzzled. Statement2: The predominant theory about northern cave paintings was that they were largely a description of the current diets of the painters. Argument: Statement1: The level of triglycerides in the blood rises when triglycerides are inadequately metabolized. Premise1: Heart disease interferes with the body's ability to metabolize triglycerides.
Premise2: Triglyceride levels above 2 milligrams per milliliter increase the risk of some serious illnesses not related to heart disease.

Statement3: In addtion, it is likely that consuming large amounts of fat, processed sugar, or alcohol, each known to increase triglyceride levels in the blood, isn't a factor causing some serious illnesses not related to heart disease.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Triglyceride levels above 2 milligrams per milliliter increase the risk of some serious illnesses not related to heart disease.
input_info.O: Premise1: Heart disease interferes with the body's ability to metabolize triglycerides.
input_info.P: Statement1: The level of triglycerides in the blood rises when triglycerides are inadequately metabolized. Argument: Statement1: The city's transportation department has noticed that the city's extensive public bus system generally runs behind schedule on days when traffic is heavier in the city. Premise2: The city owns enough buses to cover all established routes.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The city owns enough buses to cover all established routes.
input_info.O: Premise1: The city's bus-only lanes do not contribute substantially to gridlock by reducing the number of lanes available to other traffic.

Argument: Statement1: Patel : it is often thought that direct experience, unlike language and culture, can always serve as common ground for communication among human beings. Statement2: But people from different cultures inhabit different sensory worlds. Statement3: Because selective screening of sensory data admits some perceptions while filtering out others, one person's experience, perceived through one set of culturally patterned sensory screens, is quite different from what anyone from another culture would experience when encountering the same sensory data.
Premise1: No two people from different cultures have the same sensory screens.
Premise2: Two people from the same culture sometimes have different sensory screens.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Patel : it is often thought that direct experience, unlike language and culture, can always serve as common ground for communication among human beings. Statement2: But different people inhabit different sensory worlds. Statement3: Because selective screening of sensory data admits some perceptions while filtering out others, one person's experience, perceived through one set of patterned sensory screens, is probably different from what anyone from the same culture would experience when encountering the same sensory data.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption required by patel's argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Two people from the same culture sometimes have different sensory screens.
input_info.O: Premise1: No two people from different cultures have the same sensory screens.
input_info.P: Statement1: Patel : it is often thought that direct experience, unlike language and culture, can always serve as common ground for communication among human beings. Statement2: But people from different cultures inhabit different sensory worlds. Statement3: Because selective screening of sensory data admits some perceptions while filtering out others, one person's experience, perceived through one set of culturally patterned sensory screens, is quite different from what anyone from another culture would experience when encountering the same sensory data.

Argument: Statement1: Politician : the cohesion of a society depends on its members'accepting a set of basic principles. When these principles are routinely called into question, the society begins to erode. Statement2: Any society, therefore, that allows schools to present the society's set of basic principles as simply one of several alternatives, with the suggestion that students may choose which to accept on the basis of the principles'worth, is inviting its own demise.
Premise1: Given the chance to assess the merits of the principles governing their societies, individuals will rarely find those principles acceptable.
Premise2: Unless people believe that they have freely chosen to adopt the principles that govern their societies, they will tend to repudiate these principles.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Politician : the cohesion of a society depends on its members'accepting a set of basic principles. When these principles are routinely repudiated, the society begins to erode. Statement3: Any society, therefore, that does not allow schools to present the society's set of basic principles as simply one of several alternatives, with the suggestion that students may choose which to accept on the basis of the principles'worth, is inviting its own demise.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following would, if true, most strengthen the politician's argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Unless people believe that they have freely chosen to adopt the principles that govern their societies, they will tend to repudiate these principles.
input_info.O: Premise1: Given the chance to assess the merits of the principles governing their societies, individuals will rarely find those principles acceptable.
input_info.P: Statement1: Politician : the cohesion of a society depends on its members'accepting a set of basic principles. Argument: Statement1: In 1992 outlaw fishing boats began illegally harvesting lobsters from the territorial waters of the country of belukia. Soon after, the annual tonnage of lobster legally harvested in belukian waters began declining ; in 1996, despite there being no reduction in the level of legal lobster fishing activity, the local catch was 9,000 tons below pre-1992 levels. Statement2: It is therefore highly likely that the outlaw fishing boats harvested about 9,000 tons of lobster illegally that year.
Premise1: The illegal lobster harvesting was not so extensive that the population of catchable lobsters in belukia's territorial waters had sharply declined by 1996.
Premise2: Outlaw fishing boats do not, as a group, harvest more lobsters than do licensed lobster-fishing boats.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: In 1992 outlaw fishing boats began illegally harvesting lobsters from the territorial waters of the country of belukia. Soon after, the annual tonnage of lobster legally harvested in belukian waters began declining ; in 1996, there being no reduction in the level of legal lobster fishing activity, and the local catch was 9,000 tons. Statement3: It is highly likely that the outlaw fishing boats harvested lower than 9,000 tons of lobster illegally that year.

input_info.Q: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Outlaw fishing boats do not, as a group, harvest more lobsters than do licensed lobster-fishing boats.
input_info.O: Premise1: The illegal lobster harvesting was not so extensive that the population of catchable lobsters in belukia's territorial waters had sharply declined by 1996.

Argument: Statement1: Professor robinson : a large meteorite impact crater in a certain region was thought to be the clue to explaining the mass extinction of plant and animal species that occurred at the end of the mesozoic era. Premise2: The recovered rocks recrystallized shortly after they melted.

Statement3: When molten rocks crystallize, they display the polarity of earth's magnetic field at that time. Argument: Statement1: Manager : one reason productivity in our office is not as high as it could be is that office workers spend too much time taking unauthorized breaks. Statement2: Since the number of office workers assigned to each manager will soon be reduced, managers will be able to supervise workers more closely in the future to make sure that they are not taking unauthorized breaks. Statement3: Therefore, productivity in our office will soon increase.
Premise1: The gain in productivity that will result from reducing unauthorized breaks will exceed any loss in productivity caused by closer supervision.
Premise2: The best way to improve productivity is to reduce the number of employees and give more work to employees who remain on the job.

Statement2: Since the number of office workers assigned to each manager will soon be reduced, managers will be able to supervise workers who remain on the job more closely in the future to make sure that they are doing more work. Statement3: Therefore, productivity in our office will soon increase.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the manager's argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The best way to improve productivity is to reduce the number of employees and give more work to employees who remain on the job.
input_info.O: Premise1: The gain in productivity that will result from reducing unauthorized breaks will exceed any loss in productivity caused by closer supervision.

Argument: Statement1: Stage performances are judged to be realistic to the degree that actors reproduce on stage the behaviors generally associated by audiences with the emotional states of the characters portrayed. Statement2: Traditional actors imitate those behaviors, whereas method actors, through recollection of personal experience, actually experience the same emotions that their characters are meant to be experiencing. Statement3: Audiences will therefore judge the performances of method actors to be more realistic than the performances of traditional actors.
Premise1: The behavior that results when a method actor feels a certain emotion will conform to the behavior that is generally associated by audiences with that emotion.
Premise2: Performances based on an actor's own experience of emotional states are more likely to affect an audience's emotions than are performances based on imitations of the behaviors generally associated with those emotional states.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: Traditional actors imitate those behaviors, whereas method actors, through recollection of personal experience, actually experience the same emotions that their characters are meant to be experiencing. Statement3: Audiences will therefore judge the performances of method actors to affect an audience's emotions more than the performances of traditional actors.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Performances based on an actor's own experience of emotional states are more likely to affect an audience's emotions than are performances based on imitations of the behaviors generally associated with those emotional states.
input_info.O: Premise1: The behavior that results when a method actor feels a certain emotion will conform to the behavior that is generally associated by audiences with that emotion.

Argument: Statement1: In any field, experience is required for a proficient person to become an expert. Although computers have the ability to store millions of bits of information, the knowledge of human experts, who benefit from the experience of thousands of situations, is not stored within their brains in the form of rules and facts. Statement2: Through experience, a proficient person gradually develops a repertory of model situations that allows an immediate, intuitive response to each new situation. Statement3: This is the hallmark of expertise, and for this reason computerized" expert systems" can not be as good as human experts.
Premise1: The knowledge of human experts cannot be adequately rendered into the type of information that a computer can store.
Premise2: Future advances in computer technology will not render computers capable of sorting through greater amounts of information.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: In any field, experience is required for a proficient person to become an expert. Although computers have the ability to store millions of bits of information, the knowledge of human experts, who benefit from sorting through greater amounts of information, is not stored within their brains in the form of rules and facts. Statement2: Through experience, a proficient person gradually develops a repertory of model situations that allows an immediate, intuitive response to each new situation. Statement3: This is the hallmark of expertise, and for this reason computerized" expert systems" can not be as good as human experts.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Future advances in computer technology will not render computers capable of sorting through greater amounts of information.
input_info.O: Premise1: The knowledge of human experts cannot be adequately rendered into the type of information that a computer can store.

Argument: Statement1: Psychologist : some astrologers claim that our horoscopes completely determine our personalities, but this claim is false. Statement2: I concede that identical twins -- who are, of course, born at practically the same time -- often do have similar personalities. Statement3: However, birth records were examined to find two individuals who were born 40 years ago on the same day and at exactly the same time -- one in a hospital in toronto and one in a hospital in new york. Statement4: Personality tests revealed that the personalities of these two individuals are in fact different.
Premise1: The geographical difference between toronto and new york did not result in the two individuals having different horoscopes.
Premise2: The personality differences between the two individuals cannot be explained by the cultural differences between toronto and new york.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Psychologist : some astrologers claim that our horoscopes completely determine our personalities, but this claim is false. Statement2: I concede that identical twins -- who are, of course, born at practically the same time -- often do have similar personalities. Statement3: However, birth records were examined to find two individuals who were born 40 years ago on the same day and at exactly the same time -- one in a hospital in toronto and one in a hospital in new york, where culture differs from the one in toronto. Statement4: Personality tests revealed that the personalities of these two individuals are in fact different.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the psychologist's argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The personality differences between the two individuals cannot be explained by the cultural differences between toronto and new york.

Argument: Statement1: The giant chicxulub crater in mexico provides indisputable evidence that a huge asteroid, about six miles across, struck earth around the time many of the last dinosaur species were becoming extinct. Statement2: But this catastrophe was probably not responsible for most of these extinctions. Statement3: Indeed, some craters even larger than the chicxulub crater were made during times in earth's history when there were no known extinctions.

Argument: Statement1: During the month of may, crabs arrive on delaware's beaches to lay eggs. Certain shorebirds depend on these eggs for food during their annual spring migration to their northern breeding grounds. Statement2: Delaware's crab population has declined recently. Statement3: This decline, however, poses no serious threat to the migrating shorebird populations : by remaining longer in delaware, the birds will be able to eat enough crab eggs to allow them to complete their migration.
Premise1: The earlier in the season the shorebirds complete their migration, the more likely they are to breed successfully.
Premise2: No other food available to the birds on delaware's beaches is as nutritious and accessible as are crab eggs.

Statement4: This decline, however, poses no serious threat to the migrating shorebird populations : the birds can eat other replaceable food to complete their migration.

Argument: Statement1: More and more academic institutions are using citation analysis as the main technique for measuring the quality of scientific research. Statement2: This technique involves a yearly scanning of scientific journals to count the number of references to a researcher's work. Statement3: Although academic institutions want to encourage good research, use of citation analysis actually works against this goal since scientists seeking to maximize citation counts will avoid multiyear projects in favor of short-term projects in faddish areas.
Premise1: In general scientific research is not referred to in journals until the research is completed.
Premise2: Research that is initially criticized in scientific journals sometimes turns out to be groundbreaking work.

Argument: Statement1: Editor : articles in gardening magazine often spur sales of the plants they describe, particularly among people new to gardening. Argument: Statement1: Researchers took a group of teenagers who had never smoked and for one year tracked whether they took up smoking and how their mental health changed. Those who began smoking within a month of the study's start were four times as likely to be depressed at the study's end as those who did not begin smoking. Statement2: Since nicotine in cigarettes changes brain chemistry, perhaps thereby affecting mood, it is likely that smoking contributes to depression in teenagers.
Premise1: Participants who were depressed at the study's start were no more likely to be smokers at the study's end than those who were not depressed.
Premise2: Some participants entered and emerged from a period of depression within the year of the study.

Statement3: However, since nicotine in cigarettes changes brain chemistry, perhaps thereby affecting mood, it is likely that smoking contributes to depression in teenagers.

Argument: Statement1: Studies show that the most creative engineers get their best and most useful ideas only after doodling and jotting down what turn out to be outlandish ideas. Now that many engineers do their work with computers instead of on paper, however, doodling is becoming much less common, and some experts fear that the result will be fewer creative and useful engineering ideas. Statement2: These experts argue that this undesirable consequence would be avoided if computer programs for engineering work included simulated notepads that would allow engineers to suspend their" serious"work on the computer, type up outlandish ideas, and then quickly return to their original work.
Premise1: The physical act of working on paper is not essential in providing engineers with the benefits that can be gained by doodling.
Premise2: No engineers who work with computers keep paper and pencils near their computers in order to doodle and jot down ideas.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Studies show that the most creative engineers get their best and most useful ideas only after doodling and jotting down on paper what turn out to be outlandish ideas. Now that many engineers do their work with computers instead of on paper, however, doodling is becoming much less common, and some experts fear that the result will be fewer creative and useful engineering ideas. Statement3: These experts argue that this undesirable consequence would be avoided if keeping paper and pencils near their computers that would allow engineers to suspend their" serious"work, write down outlandish ideas, and then quickly return to their original work.

input_info.Om: Premise2: No engineers who work with computers keep paper and pencils near their computers in order to doodle and jot down ideas.
input_info.O: Premise1: The physical act of working on paper is not essential in providing engineers with the benefits that can be gained by doodling.

Argument: Statement1: Although many seventeenth-century broadsides, popular ballads printed on a single sheet of paper and widely sold by street peddlers, were moralizing in nature, this is not evidence that most seventeenth-century people were serious about moral values. Statement2: While over half of surviving broadsides contain moralizing statements, and it is known that many people purchased such compositions, it is not known why they did so, nor is it known how their own beliefs related to what they read.
Premise1: In many moralizing ballads, the moral content was confined to a single stanza expressing a pious sentiment tacked onto a sensationalized account of crime and adultery.
Premise2: Well-educated people of the seventeenth century held broadsides in contempt and considered broadside peddlers to be disreputable vagrants.

Argument: Statement1: In 1563, in florence's palazzo vecchio, giorgio vasari built in front of an existing wall a new wall on which he painted a mural. Statement2: Investigators recently discovered a gap between vasari's wall and the original, large enough to have preserved anything painted on the original. Statement3: Historians believe that leonardo da vinci had painted, but left unfinished, a mural on the original wall ; some historians had also believed that by 1563 the mural had been destroyed. Statement4: However, it is known that in the late 1560s, when renovating another building, santa marianovella, vasari built a facade over its frescoes, and the frescoes were thereby preserved. Statement5: Thus, leonardo's palazzo vecchio mural probably still exists behind vasari's wall.
Premise1: Vasari probably would not have built the palazzo vecchio wall with a gap behind it except to preserve something behind the new wall.
Premise2: Leonardo would probably have completed the palazzo vecchio mural if he had had the opportunity to do so.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: In 1563, in florence's palazzo vecchio, giorgio vasari built in front of an existing wall a new wall on which he painted a mural. Statement2: Investigators recently discovered a gap between vasari's wall and the original, large enough to have preserved anything painted on the original. Statement3: Historians believe that leonardo da vinci had painted, but left unfinished, a mural on the original wall ; some historians had also believed that by 1563 the mural had been destroyed because of its unfinishment. Statement4: However, it is known that in the late 1560s, when renovating another building, santa marianovella, vasari built a facade over its frescoes, and the frescoes were thereby preserved. Statement5: Thus, leonardo's palazzo vecchio mural probably still exists.

input_info.Q: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Leonardo would probably have completed the palazzo vecchio mural if he had had the opportunity to do so.
input_info.O: Premise1: Vasari probably would not have built the palazzo vecchio wall with a gap behind it except to preserve something behind the new wall.
input_info.P: Statement1: In 1563, in florence's palazzo vecchio, giorgio vasari built in front of an existing wall a new wall on which he painted a mural. Statement2: Investigators recently discovered a gap between vasari's wall and the original, large enough to have preserved anything painted on the original. Statement3: Historians believe that leonardo da vinci had painted, but left unfinished, a mural on the original wall ; some historians had also believed that by 1563 the mural had been destroyed. Statement4: However, it is known that in the late 1560s, when renovating another building, santa marianovella, vasari built a facade over its frescoes, and the frescoes were thereby preserved. Statement5: Thus, leonardo's palazzo vecchio mural probably still exists behind vasari's wall.

Argument: Statement1: In 1974 the speed limit on highways in the united states was reduced to 55 miles per hour in order to save fuel. Premise1: The fatality rate in highway accidents involving motorists driving faster than 55 miles per hour is much higher than in highway accidents that do not involve motorists driving at such speeds.
Premise2: Motorists are more likely to avoid accidents by matching their speed to that of the surrounding highway traffic than by driving at faster or slower speeds.

Over the next 10 years, the fatality rate declined by another 25 percent. Statement4: It follows that the 1974 reduction in the speed limit saved many lives.
