Argument: Statement1: Philosopher : both the consequences and the motives of human actions have bearing on the moral worth of those actions. Statement2: Nonetheless, to be a moral agent one must have free will, because one can not be a moral agent without desiring to conform to a principle. 
Premise1: Desiring to conform to a principle requires free will 
Premise2: It is impossible to have desires without also being a moral agent

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: Philosopher : both the consequences and the motives of human actions have bearing on the moral worth of those actions. Statement2: Nonetheless, one can not have desires without desiring to conform to a principle, because one can not be a moral agent without desiring to conform to a principle.

Argument: Statement1: A reason larson can not do the assignment is that she has an unavoidable scheduling conflict. Statement2: On the other hand, a reason franks can not do the assignment is that he does not quite have the assertiveness the task requires. Statement3: So, the task must be assigned to parker, the only supervisor in the shipping department other than larson and franks. 
Premise1: The task cannot be assigned to anyone other than a supervisor in the shipping department. 
Premise2: The task cannot be assigned to anyone who has any kind of scheduling conflict.

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: A reason larson can not do the assignment is that she has an unavoidable scheduling conflict. Statement2: On the other hand, a reason franks can not do the assignment is that he does not quite have the assertiveness the task requires. Statement3: So, the task must be assigned to parker, the only one who do not have scheduling conflict in the shipping department other than larson and franks.

Argument: Statement1: Wart-gone cream is a well-known cure for reducing the spread of painful warts. A dime size amount rubbed on the infected area daily is the prescribed dosage, and applying the cream more often does not enhance the cream's healing effects. Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will not boost sales and, therefore, will not increase profits either. 
Premise1: The $3. 00 coupons, if distributed, would not induce new customers, who might not have purchased the product otherwise, to try wart-gone. 
Premise2: Wart-gone can be produced in small or large batches without appreciably lowering the pre-tube production costs.

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: Wart-gone cream is a well-known cure for reducing the spread of painful warts. A dime size amount rubbed on the infected area daily is the prescribed dosage, and applying the cream more often can enhance the cream's healing effects. Statement3: Hence, distributing coupons giving $ 3.00 off the price of wart-gone will boost produce and, however, will not change pre-tube production costs much.

Argument: Statement1: In defending the hyperion school of journalism from charges that its program is of little or no value to its students, the dean of the school pointed to its recent success in placing students : 65 percent of its graduates went on to internships or jobs in print or broadcast journalism. 
Premise1: More than half of the school's students came from jobs in journalism to improve their skills. 
Premise2: Some newspaper editors do not regard journalism schools as a necessary part of the training of a journalist.

Please write the modified argument below:

Modified Argument:
Statement1: In defending the hyperion school of journalism from charges that its program is of little or no value to its students, the dean of the school pointed to its recent success in placing students : the journalism regards journalism schools as a necessary part of the training of a journalist.

Argument: Statement1: The more frequently employees take time to exercise during working hours each week, the fewer sick days they take. Even employees who exercise only once a week during working hours take less sick time than those who do not exercise. Statement2: Therefore, if companies started fitness programs, the absentee rate in those companies would decrease significantly.
Premise1: Employees who are frequently absent are the least likely to cooperate with or to join a corporate fitness program.
Premise2: Employees who exercise only once a week in their company's fitness program usually also exercise after work.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The more frequently employees take time to exercise during working hours each week, the fewer sick days they take. Even employees who exercise only once a week during working hours take less sick time than those who do not exercise. Statement3: Therefore, if companies started fitness programs that everyone must exercise at least once a week, the absentee rate in those companies would decrease significantly.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument above?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Employees who exercise only once a week in their company's fitness program usually also exercise after work.
input_info.O: Premise1: Employees who are frequently absent are the least likely to cooperate with or to join a corporate fitness program.
input_info.P: Statement1: The more frequently employees take time to exercise during working hours each week, the fewer sick days they take. Even employees who exercise only once a week during working hours take less sick time than those who do not exercise. Statement2: Therefore, if companies started fitness programs, the absentee rate in those companies would decrease significantly.

Argument: Statement1: Bacteria from food can survive for several days on the surface of plastic cutting boards, but bacteria can penetrate wooden cutting boards almost immediately, leaving the surface free of contamination. Statement2: Therefore, wooden cutting boards, unlike plastic cutting boards, need not be washed in order to prevent their contaminating food that is cut on them ; wiping them off to remove food debris is sufficient.
Premise1: Bacteria that penetrate into wooden cutting boards do not reemerge on the surface after the cutting boards have been used.
Premise2: Washing plastic cutting boards does not remove all bacteria from the surface.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Bacteria from food can survive for several days on the surface of plastic cutting boards, but bacteria can penetrate wooden cutting boards almost immediately, leaving the surface free of contamination. Statement2: Therefore, wooden cutting boards, unlike plastic cutting boards, could be washed totally clean in order to prevent their contaminating food that is cut on them ; wiping them off to remove food debris is sufficient.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Washing plastic cutting boards does not remove all bacteria from the surface.
input_info.O: Premise1: Bacteria that penetrate into wooden cutting boards do not reemerge on the surface after the cutting boards have been used.
input_info.P: Statement1: Bacteria from food can survive for several days on the surface of plastic cutting boards, but bacteria can penetrate wooden cutting boards almost immediately, leaving the surface free of contamination. Statement2: Therefore, wooden cutting boards, unlike plastic cutting boards, need not be washed in order to prevent their contaminating food that is cut on them ; wiping them off to remove food debris is sufficient.

Argument: Statement1: Last year a chain of fast-food restaurants, whose menu had always centered on hamburger, added its first vegetarian sandwich, much lower in fat than the chain 's other offerings. Statement2: Despite heavy marketing, the new sandwich accounts for a very small proportion of the chain 's sales. The sandwich 's sales would have to quadruple to cover the costs associated with including it on the menu. Statement3: Since such an increase is unlikely, the chain would be more profitable if it dropped the sandwich.
Premise1: When even one member of group of diner's is a vegetarian or has a preference for low-fat food, the group tends to avoid restaurants that lack vegetarian or low-fat menu options.
Premise2: An attempt by the chain to introduce a lower-fat hamburger failed several years ago, since it attracted few new customers and most of the chain's regular customers greatly preferred the taste of the regular hamburger.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Last year a chain of fast-food restaurants, whose menu had always centered on hamburger, added its first vegetarian sandwich, much lower in fat than the chain 's other offerings. Statement2: Despite heavy marketing, the new sandwich accounts for a very small proportion of the chain 's sales. The sandwich 's sales would have to quadruple to cover the costs associated with including it on the menu. Statement4: Since such an increase is possible, the chain would be more profitable if it continued offering the sandwich.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: An attempt by the chain to introduce a lower-fat hamburger failed several years ago, since it attracted few new customers and most of the chain's regular customers greatly preferred the taste of the regular hamburger.
input_info.O: Premise1: When even one member of group of diner's is a vegetarian or has a preference for low-fat food, the group tends to avoid restaurants that lack vegetarian or low-fat menu options.
input_info.P: Statement1: Last year a chain of fast-food restaurants, whose menu had always centered on hamburger, added its first vegetarian sandwich, much lower in fat than the chain 's other offerings. Statement2: Despite heavy marketing, the new sandwich accounts for a very small proportion of the chain 's sales. The sandwich 's sales would have to quadruple to cover the costs associated with including it on the menu. Statement3: Since such an increase is unlikely, the chain would be more profitable if it dropped the sandwich.

Argument: Statement1: A museum has been offered an undocumented statue, supposedly greek and from the sixth century b.c. Statement2: Possibly the statue is genuine but undocumented because it was recently unearthed or because it has been privately owned. However, an ancient surface usually has uneven weathering, whereas the surface of this statue has the uniform quality characteristically produced by a chemical bath used by forgers to imitate a weathered surface. Statement3: Therefore, the statue is probably a forgery.
Premise1: The chemical bath that forgers use was at one time used by dealers and collectors to remove the splotchy surface appearance of genuinely ancient sculptures.
Premise2: An allegedly roman sculpture with a uniform surface similar to that of the statue being offered to the museum was recently shown to be a forgery.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A museum has been offered an undocumented statue, supposedly greek and from the sixth century b.c. Statement2: Possibly the statue is genuine but undocumented because it was recently unearthed or because it has been privately owned. However, an ancient surface usually has uneven weathering, whereas the surface of this statue has the uniform quality characteristically produced by a chemical bath used by collectors to remove the splotchy surface appearance. Statement4: Therefore, the statue is probably genuine.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: An allegedly roman sculpture with a uniform surface similar to that of the statue being offered to the museum was recently shown to be a forgery.
input_info.O: Premise1: The chemical bath that forgers use was at one time used by dealers and collectors to remove the splotchy surface appearance of genuinely ancient sculptures.

Statement3: Therefore, the statue is probably a forgery.

Argument: Statement1: A naturally occurring deposit of radioactive material similar in composition to the dangerous waste produced by applications of nuclear technology has been found deep within the earth's crust. Statement2: No ill effects have been traced to this naturally occurring deposit. Statement3: Since engineers have now developed a way to store manufactured nuclear waste as deeply within the earth's crust as the recently found natural radioactive deposit, the safe disposal of nuclear waste can now be initiated.
Premise1: It cannot currently be determined what the geological conditions are under which the naturally occurring radioactive deposit has apparently been safely contained.
Premise2: Continued production of nuclear waste at the current rate will eventually outstrip available capacity for safe storage.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A naturally occurring deposit of radioactive material similar in composition to the dangerous waste produced by applications of nuclear technology has been found deep within the earth's crust. Statement2: No ill effects have been traced to this naturally occurring deposit. Statement3: Since engineers have now developed a way take advantage of the space underground to store manufactured nuclear waste as deeply within the earth's crust as the recently found natural radioactive deposit, the safe disposal of nuclear waste can now be initiated.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Continued production of nuclear waste at the current rate will eventually outstrip available capacity for safe storage.

Argument: Statement1: Climatologist : over the coming century, winter temperatures are likely to increase in the rocky mountains due to global warming. Statement2: This will cause a greater proportion of precipitation to fall as rain instead of snow. Statement3: Therefore, the mountain snowpack will probably melt more rapidly and earlier in the season, leading to greater spring flooding and less storable water to meet summer demands.
Premise1: In other mountainous regions after relatively mild winters, the melting of snowpacks has led to greater spring flooding and less storable water, on average, than in those mountainous regions after colder winters.
Premise2: The larger a mountain snowpack is, the greater the amount of spring flooding it is likely to be responsible for producing.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Climatologist : over the coming century, winter temperatures are likely to decrease in the rocky mountains due to global climate change. Statement2: This will cause a greater proportion of precipitation to fall as snow instead of rain. Statement3: Therefore, the mountain snowpack will probably melt more slowly and later in the season, becoming a larger snowpack and less storable water to meet summer demands.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The larger a mountain snowpack is, the greater the amount of spring flooding it is likely to be responsible for producing.

Argument: Statement1: A positive correlation has been found between the amount of soot in the atmosphere of cities and the frequency of a certain ailment among those cities'populations. Statement2: However, the soot itself probably does not cause this ailment, since in cities where there are large amounts of soot in the air, there are usually also high concentrations of many other air pollutants.

Argument: Statement1: Sigatoka disease drastically reduces the yield of banana trees and is epidemic throughout the areas of the world where bananas are grown. The fungus that causes the disease can be controlled with fungicides, but the fungicides can pose a health hazard to people living nearby. Argument: Statement1: Editorial : the structure of the present school calendar was established to satisfy the requirements of early-twentieth-century agricultural life. Statement3: The contemporary school year is thus made up of periods of study interspersed with long breaks. Statement4: Therefore, long breaks should be removed from the school calendar.

Premise2: During long breaks children have a tendency to forget what they have learned.

Statement3: The contemporary school year is thus made up of periods of study interspersed with long breaks. Statement5: Therefore, long breaks should be removed from the school calendar.

input_info.Om: Premise2: During long breaks children have a tendency to forget what they have learned.

Argument: Statement1: A cup of raw milk, after being heated in a microwave oven to 50 degrees celsius, contains half its initial concentration of a particular enzyme, lysozyme. If, however, the milk reaches that temperature through exposure to a conventional heat source of 50 degrees celsius, it will contain nearly all of its initial concentration of the enzyme. Statement2: Therefore, what destroys the enzyme is not heat but microwaves, which generate heat.
Premise1: Heating any liquid by microwave creates small zones within it that are much hotter than the overall temperature that the liquid will ultimately reach.
Premise2: Heating raw milk in a microwave oven to a temperature of 100 degrees celsius destroys nearly all of the lysozyme initially present in that milk.

Statement3: But, what destroys the enzyme is heat, not microwaves, which generate heat.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Heating raw milk in a microwave oven to a temperature of 100 degrees celsius destroys nearly all of the lysozyme initially present in that milk.

Argument: Statement1: Most household appliances use electricity only when in use. Premise1: Households whose microwave oven does not have a built-in clock are no more likely to have a separate electric clock plugged in than households whose microwave oven has one.
Premise2: Households that do not have a microwave oven use less energy per year, on average, than do households that have a microwave oven.

Statement4: Therefore, households whose do not have microwave spend less money on energy, on average, than do comparable households whose microwave has a built-in clock.

input_info.Q: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?

Argument: Statement1: Blogger : traditionally, newspapers have taken objectivity to be an essential of good journalism. However, today's newer media are more inclined to try to create a stir with openly partisan reporting. Statement2: This contrast in journalistic standards is best understood in terms of differing business strategies. Statement3: The newer media outlets need to differentiate themselves in a crowded marketplace. Statement4: The standard of objectivity developed primarily among newspapers with no serious rivals, so the most important objective was to avoid offending potential readers.

Premise2: People prefer objective reporting to partisan reporting that merely reinforces their own partisan leanings.

Statement3: This contrast in journalistic standards is best understood in terms of differing business strategies. Statement4: The newer media outlets need to differentiate themselves in a crowded marketplace. Statement5: The standard of objectivity developed primarily among newspapers with no serious rivals, so the most important objective was to attract more readers.

input_info.Om: Premise2: People prefer objective reporting to partisan reporting that merely reinforces their own partisan leanings.
input_info.O: Premise1: Newspapers have regarded objective reporting as less likely to offend people than openly partisan reporting.

Argument: Statement1: If the flowers drew received today had been sent by someone who knows drew well, that person would have known that drew prefers violets to roses. Yet drew received roses. Statement2: On the other hand, if the flowers had been sent by someone who does not know drew well, then that person would have sent a signed card with the flowers. Yet drew received no card. Statement3: Therefore, the florist must have made some sort of mistake : either drew was supposed to receive violets, or a card, or these flowers were intended for someone else.

Premise2: Someone who does not know drew well would be unlikely to send drew flowers.

Argument: Statement1: When storing renaissance oil paintings, museums conform to standards that call for careful control of the surrounding temperature and humidity, with variations confined within narrow margins. Statement2: Maintaining this environment is very costly, and recent research shows that even old oil paint is unaffected by wide fluctuations in temperature and humidity. Statement3: Therefore, museums could relax their standards and save money without endangering their renaissance oil paintings.

Premise2: Under the current standards that museums use when storing renaissance oil paintings, those paintings do not deteriorate at all.

Statement3: Therefore, museums should insist their standards and protect safely their renaissance oil paintings.

Argument: Statement1: Enthusiasm for the use of calculators in the learning of mathematics is misplaced. Statement2: Teachers rightly observe that in some cases calculators enable students to focus on general principles rather than the tedious, largely rote calculations that constitute the application of these principles. But principles are more likely to be remembered when knowledge of them is grounded in habits ingrained by painstaking applications of those principles. Statement3: The very fact that calculators make calculation easier, therefore, makes it reasonable to restrict their use.
Premise1: It is much more important that students retain the knowledge of general principles than that this knowledge be easily acquired.
Premise2: Habits that are acquired by laborious and sometimes tedious practice are not as valuable as those that are painlessly mastered.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Enthusiasm for the use of calculators in the learning of mathematics is good. Statement2: Teachers rightly observe that in some cases calculators enable students to focus on general principles rather than the tedious, largely rote calculations that constitute the application of these principles. Although habbit is more likely to be remembered when knowledge of them is grounded in habits ingrained by painstaking applications of those principles. Statement4: The habbit that using calculators makes calculation easier, therefore, makes caculators reasonable to use.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Habits that are acquired by laborious and sometimes tedious practice are not as valuable as those that are painlessly mastered.
input_info.O: Premise1: It is much more important that students retain the knowledge of general principles than that this knowledge be easily acquired.
input_info.P: Statement1: Enthusiasm for the use of calculators in the learning of mathematics is misplaced. Statement2: Teachers rightly observe that in some cases calculators enable students to focus on general principles rather than the tedious, largely rote calculations that constitute the application of these principles. But principles are more likely to be remembered when knowledge of them is grounded in habits ingrained by painstaking applications of those principles. Statement3: The very fact that calculators make calculation easier, therefore, makes it reasonable to restrict their use.

Statement3: Any computer program is merely the implementation of a methodology.
Premise1: Large corporations should not hold patents for implementations of methodologies.
Premise2: Computer programs should be developed not only by large corporations but by small-time inventors as well.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The current move to patent computer programs is a move in the wrong direction and should be stopped. Statement2: The patent system was originally designed solely to protect small-time inventors from exploitation, not to give large corporations control over development rights. Statement3: Any computer program should be developed by anybody.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Computer programs should be developed not only by large corporations but by small-time inventors as well.
input_info.O: Premise1: Large corporations should not hold patents for implementations of methodologies.

Statement3: Any computer program is merely the implementation of a methodology.

Argument: Statement1: Science writer : sent2: the deterioration of cognitive faculties associated with alzheimer's disease is evidently caused by the activities of microglia -- the brain's own immune cells. Argument: Statement1: The only physical factor preventing a human journey to mars has been weight. Carrying enough fuel to propel a conventional spacecraft to mars and back would make even the lightest craft too heavy to be launched from earth. Statement2: A device has recently been invented, however, that allows an otherwise conventional spacecraft to refill the craft's fuel tanks with fuel manufactured from the martian atmosphere for the return trip. Statement3: Therefore, it is possible for people to go to mars in a spacecraft that carries this device and then return.

Premise2: The device for manufacturing fuel from the martian atmosphere would not take up any of the spaceship crew's living space.

Statement4: Therefore, it is possible for people to go to mars in a spacecraft that carries this device and then return.

Argument: Statement1: After a hepadnavirus inserts itself into a chromosome of an animal, fragments of the virus are passed on to all of that animal's descendants. Statement2: A hepadnavirus fragment is present in a chromosome of the zebra finch and in precisely the same location in a corresponding chromosome of the dark-eyed junco. Statement3: The fact that these two bird species diverged from each other about 25 million years ago therefore means that the hepadnavirus is at least 25 million years old.

Statement3: The fact that these two bird species diverged from each other about 25 million years ago therefore may not mean that the hepadnavirus is at least 25 million years old.
